item.title: Gaza | Xi calls for the Strip to be under Palestinian control
item.description: The Chinese President called for the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip to be carried out under the principle of “Palestinians govern Palestine” and urged the international community to promote a “comprehensive and lasting ceasefire”. Xi Jinping stated that the Palestinian issue “affects international equity and justice” and constitutes “a test of the effectiveness of the global governance system”, said the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In a message sent to a UN meeting on Tuesday, the Chinese leader argued that the international community must “take responsibility, correct historical injustices and defend justice”. On the occasion of the International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People, Xi stressed that any post-war structure must respect “the will of the Palestinian people” and take into account the legitimate concerns of countries in the region. The Chinese leader insisted that efforts must “be anchored in the two-state solution” to achieve a “comprehensive, fair and lasting” political agreement. The Chinese President said that the immediate priority is to improve the humanitarian situation and alleviate the suffering of civilians in Gaza, and reiterated that Beijing, as a permanent member of the Security Council, “will continue to support the just cause of the Palestinian people to restore their legitimate national rights”.

item.title: DSPA | Renewed Director Service Committee
item.description: Ip Kuong Lam's service commission as director of Environmental Protection Services has been renewed for a period of one year, according to an order published yesterday in the Official Gazette. As happens in these situations, the order indicates that the appointee has “appropriate experience and professional capacity to carry out his duties”. Ip Kuong Lam has a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in Environmental Engineering. He entered the public service in 2001, and served as senior technician at the Environment Council, head of the Environmental Pollution Control Department at DSPA and deputy director of DSPA, between 2014 and 2024, when he was promoted to his current position. IH | Iam Lei Leng's mandate renewed The mandate of the president of the Housing Institute (IH), Iam Lei Leng, was renewed for a period of one year, according to an order published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. Iam was first appointed to these roles in 2023, during Raimundo do Rosário's period as Secretary for Transport and Public Works. The renewal of the mandate was justified by the fact that Iam had “appropriate experience and professional capacity to carry out his duties”. Before being appointed president of IH, Iam Lei Leng headed the Department of Studies at the Housing Institute since March 2015. The current president joined IH, as a technician, in April 1999, remaining in the position for around a year. Between June 2002 and January 2006, he became a senior technician. After completing this mission, he became head of Legal Affairs at the Housing Institute, where he remained until 2015. item.title: ‘Satellite casinos’ | Kam Pek closes doors in Macau
item.description: Macau gaming concessionaire SJM Resorts announced yesterday that the Kam Pek Paradise 'satellite casino', with almost 600 employees, will close on December 1st. SJM said that Kam Pek Parasise “will officially cease operations at 23:59 (Monday, December 1st), thus becoming the seventh ‘satellite casino’ in the region to close its doors. In a statement, SJM, founded by gaming tycoon Stanley Ho Hung Sun (1921-2020), highlighted that all local employees directly hired by the company have guaranteed employment. SJM explained that staff with resident status in Macau will be “transferred to other company casinos to perform gaming-related functions, according to operational needs”. Local employees who were not hired directly by SJM Resorts “are invited to apply for related vacancies” within the group, “with priority for hiring” and with conditions equal to those they had. Also yesterday, the Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Department (DICJ) assured that it will “strictly supervise, on site, the closure procedures” of Kam Pek Paradise. With regard to the 584 casino employees, the DICJ assured, in a press release, that it will maintain communication with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs, to ensure compliance with the guarantees given by the SJM, namely “the relocation of all aforementioned workers”. SJM highlighted that “all tables and gaming machines currently operating on site will be transferred to other company casinos”.

item.title: Edgar Martins wins Grand Prize Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize 2025
item.description: Photographer Edgar Martins won the Grand Prize of the Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize 2025, worth 25 thousand euros, for the work “Anton’s Hand is Made of Guilt”, inspired by the disappearance of a friend during wartime. The announcement was made this Tuesday, the day of the opening of the finalists' exhibition, at the Sociedade Nacional de Belas Artes, in Lisbon, during a press visit, led by Howard Bilton, founder and president of the Sovereign Art Foundation (SAF). This is the fourth edition of this annual award, which is awarded by the SAF Association, the Portuguese branch of the Sovereign Art Foundation, created in 2003 in Hong Kong to promote, support and recognize contemporary art and encourage artistic production, as well as financing programs for disadvantaged children in Portugal. The winning work, which is also present in the collection of the Museu de Arte Contemporânea Armando Martins (MACAM), is a chromogenic proof, mounted in aluminum and framed, which is part of the series “Anton’s hand is made of Guilt. No muscle of Bone. He has a Gung-ho Finger and a Grief-stricken Thumb” (2023). Edgar Martins' work explores themes such as war, incarceration, migration, urbanism and technology, with this project, in particular, focusing on the death and disappearance of a friend, photojournalist Anton Hammerl, during the Libyan war in 2011. Central questions The work is articulated around a central question: how to narrate a story without witnesses, evidence or traces, and in the absence of the photographic referent itself”, states the catalog information about the work, adding that “more than a tribute, this work portrays a complex story, distorted by absences, which talks about the difficulties of documenting, witnessing and imagining war”. "While I don't tend to categorize my work as photography in the traditional sense of the term, it is, in virtually every way, photographic. And photography, historically, has not been particularly successful when it is forced to compete with other mediums. So I received this news with surprise and excitement in equal measure. It is, of course, a huge honor to receive such a prestigious award. And what's more, a privilege to know that this financial support will directly contribute to the Sovereign Art Foundation's solidarity program, making me feel part of of something much greater than this isolated artistic feat”, declared the winner, quoted in a statement. For the president of the jury, David Elliott, it has not been an easy task to find a winner, with the “variety, depth and subtlety of the finalist works”. "The cruelly savage ironies that confront us in every daily news report are part of the theme of Edgar Martins' winning work. Rooted in both the present and the recent past, it was triggered by the still unexplained disappearance and death of his friend, photojournalist Anton Hammerl, during the Libyan War in 2011. It remains a crime without witnesses or any other evidence, a void that Martins has addressed in other works, as well as in the winning work 'Anton's Hand is Made of Guilt. In Muscle or Bone. He has a Gung-ho Finger and a Grief-stricken Thumb'”, said the president of the jury, quoted by the organization. In female This year, for the first time, the Women's Prize was created, created in partnership with the Sassy Women Society, worth two thousand euros, which distinguishes the finalist with the highest score, with the choice going to the artist Alice Marcelino, for the work “Black Skin White Algorithm”. The 30 finalist works will be on display until December 13th, the date on which the Public Vote prize will be awarded, which can be done in person or online, also worth two thousand euros. The 30 finalist works that will be on display were chosen by an international jury made up of seven experts – Adelaide Ginga, Armando Cabral, David Eliott, Francisco Trêpa (who won the grand prize in 2024), João Paulo Queiroz, Maura Marvão and Tim Marlow OBE – from around 200 artists proposed by a panel of independent arts professionals, including Portuguese critics, curators and academics. All finalist works are available for purchase and profits will be divided equally between the artists and SAF's expressive arts programs for disadvantaged children in Portugal. The Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize is an annual award that celebrates the work of contemporary artists living in Portugal and its diaspora, offering international recognition and financially supporting artists, whilst also raising funds for disadvantaged children in Portugal through the sale of finalist works.

item.title: Hong Kong | At least 13 people died in a fire
item.description: The images of the fire that spread through the apartment blocks with capacity for 2,000 people suggest a major tragedy At least 12 people died yesterday in a fire that spread to several buildings in a Hong Kong housing complex, according to the Chinese press, highlighting that there were people trapped in the apartments. According to the South China Morning Post portal, 12 people, including a firefighter, died and at least 16 others were seriously injured in the fire that devastated the Tai Po neighborhood. The other 11 fatalities were eight women and three men, according to sources cited by the media outlet. The flames consumed bamboo scaffolding in all eight buildings in the social neighborhood, leaving several other residents trapped inside the apartments, according to the Chinese news portal. The director of the local fire department, Andy Yeung, told reporters that one firefighter was among the dead and another had to receive medical treatment for heat exhaustion. According to the Associated Press (AP) news agency, videos from the scene showed at least five buildings close to each other in flames, with smoke coming out of many apartment windows, as night fell. Firefighters fought the flames by throwing water from the ladders of the corporation's trucks. The violent fire released a column of flames and dense smoke as it spread through the bamboo scaffolding and protective screens installed around the buildings, located in the Tai Po district. Records show the housing complex is made up of eight buildings with almost 2,000 apartments. Hong Kong police said they had received several reports of people trapped in fire-stricken buildings, but did not provide details. Maximum level The fire was reported in the middle of the afternoon and, after dark, authorities raised it to alert level 5, the highest level of severity, according to the fire department. Tai Po district authorities opened temporary shelters for people left homeless by the fire. Tai Po is a suburban area in the New Territories, in the northern part of Hong Kong and close to the border with the city of Shenzhen in mainland China. Bamboo scaffolding is common in Hong Kong in building construction and renovation projects, although the Government announced earlier this year that it would begin phasing it out of public projects due to safety concerns.

item.title: Cambodia | Money laundering suspicions in Macau
item.description: Companies linked to the Prince Holding group and Chen Zhi, accused of cybercrime, human trafficking and money laundering, conducted business in Macau and Hong Kong. One of the companies was Companhia de Vinho Pou Long, which operated in the Macao SAR and even organized a gala dinner for the elderly in 2020 Octopus tentacles from a dismantled scam center in Cambodia may have reached Macau and Hong Kong. An investigation by the HK01 portal revealed that companies related to billionaire Chen Zhi's criminal empire operated in the special administrative regions. The 37-year-old Chinese businessman is seen as the “brain behind a criminal empire” and is at the center of the largest cryptocurrency seizure in history, with around $14 billion in bitcoins confiscated by the United States Treasury Department. The schemes allegedly operated in industrial complexes in Cambodia, where foreign workers were forced to commit online fraud under armed surveillance. According to the Hong Kong publication, in the Prince Holding business universe, chaired by the Fujian businessman, there are companies that had business in Macau selling alcoholic beverages through a network of companies that had as a common denominator a businessman also active in Hong Kong: Qiu Yong. The businessman, who appears on the list of 146 companies and people sanctioned by the United States due to the alleged commission of the crimes mentioned above, holds passports from Cambodia and Saint Lucia, a small island in the Caribbean, and was the main shareholder of eight companies based in Hong Kong, two of which have already been dissolved. One of the companies based and operating in the neighboring region was the Wine Mini Store Digital Economy Industry Company, led together with Ng Sang Lei, a Macau resident and Macao SAR passport holder. A web in the delta The Wine Mini Store had a commercial address in Tsim Sha Tsui in the same place where several companies were headquartered that fugitive billionaire Chen Zhi controlled indirectly through offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands and companies in Hong Kong. Among the companies created and dissolved is the Pou Long Wine Company, based in Tsim Sha Tsui, which was fully owned by Ng Sang Lei before the commercial registration was annulled in October this year. According to reports in Macau in the past, the Pou Long Wine Company launched a series of activities, including a gala dinner for the elderly, in January 2020, which was attended by Qiu Yong. In February 2020, during the outbreak of Covid-19 in Wuhan, the Pou Long Wine Company donated 1.5 million patacas and 60,000 masks to the provincial authorities. In relation to the Macau resident, HM found references to Ng Sang Lei in the Official Gazette, when she was authorized by the Macau Monetary Authority to practice as an insurance intermediary in the Macao SAR in June 2019. Less than 10 months later, the resident was the target of an infringement procedure.

item.title: Sports Garden | Zone 1 works awarded for 1.34 billion
item.description: The Public Works Services Department (DSOP) announced the award of the work to the consortium made up of Grupo Construção Omas Limitada, Companhia de Engenharia de Túneis Shanghai S.A., and China Zhong Ji Indústria e Instabilidade (Macau) Lda. The construction of Zone 1 of the future Sports Garden for Citizens, on the former Canídromo site, was awarded 1.34 billion patacas, according to information released by the Public Works Services Department (DSOP). The work was awarded to the consortium made up of Grupo Construção Omas Limitada, Companhia de Engenharia de Túneis Shanghai S.A., and China Zhong Ji Indústria e Instacção (Macau) Lda. This consortium presented the cheapest new proposal, among the 17 accepted in the public tender. Regarding the period of work, the consortium committed to completing the works in 964 days, the second fastest period. This period was also presented by eight other proposals. The competition jury rejected the proposal from the consortium Companhia de Construção e Engenharia Rock-One, Limitada, Rock-One Imobiliária Empresa Limitada and Rock-One Desenvolvimento Empresa Limitada, which presented the lowest price, of 1.27 billion patacas, as well as the shortest deadline, for a total of 913 days. Work plan The Sports Garden covers an area of ​​40,425 square meters and will be divided into four pavilions, in addition to including an outdoor athletics track and a basement. The first pavilion with four floors includes two swimming pools, one of which is for children, a basketball court, and a running track and cycle path. In the second pavilion, with six floors, a skate park, tennis courts, climbing area, volleyball and badminton courts will be built. Regarding the third pavilion, the project envisages a seven-story building to house a five-a-side football field, a two-story multipurpose room, a multipurpose activity room and spaces for outdoor activities. Finally, the fourth pavilion is designed for children, and according to the project, it envisages the construction of an outdoor activity area, a children's playground and classrooms and reading rooms. In the basement, there will be a public parking lot with 69 spaces for cars and 166 spaces for motorcycles. There will be another parking lot, to be built in the second phase, with 415 parking spaces for light vehicles and 425 for motorcycles. The works are divided into Zone 1 and Zone 2. Work in Zone 1 will start first and includes the demolition of existing structures on the land and the construction of the pavilions, excluding the one dedicated to children, the basement and the smaller car park.

item.title: Finance | Reserve with biggest increase until September since the pandemic
item.description: In nine months, the value of reserve assets increased by 42.5 billion patacas, exceeding last year's figure. Macau's financial reserve is at its highest level since April 2021, with a value of 658.8 billion patacas The financial reserve had the best first nine months of the year since 2019, before the start of the covid-19 pandemic, it was announced yesterday. According to a balance sheet published in the Official Bulletin by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM), the value of assets rose by 42.5 billion patacas in the first nine months. Official data show that this is the best start to the year since the first nine months of 2019, a period in which the reserve appreciated by 64.7 billion patacas. According to AMCM, the reserve has already appreciated more than in 2024, the year in which assets rose by 35.7 billion patacas, the highest annual value since the pandemic. Last year recorded the highest increase since 2019, when the value of Macau's financial reserve rose by 70.6 billion patacas. In September alone, the reserve gained 5.49 billion patacas, reaching 658.7 billion patacas, the highest value in more than four years. Macau's financial reserve is at the highest level since recorded in April 2021, at 658.8 billion patacas. Still, it remains below the historical record of 663.6 billion patacas, reached at the end of February 2021, despite the territory being in the midst of a pandemic at the time. The inside of the melon The value of the extraordinary reserve at the end of September this year was 456.5 billion patacas and the basic reserve, equivalent to 150 percent of Macau's public budget, was 167.3 billion patacas. Subcontracted investments represent the largest share of Macau's financial reserve, 281.3 billion patacas, which also includes deposits and current accounts worth 265.4 billion patacas and even credit securities worth 109.4 billion patacas. In 2024, investments yielded almost 31 billion patacas to the financial reserve, corresponding to a profitability rate of 5.3 percent, said AMCM, at the end of February. The territory's initial budget for 2025 predicted a 7 percent increase in total expenditure, to 109.4 billion patacas. But the Legislative Assembly (AL) approved in July a proposal presented by the Government for a new budget, which includes an extra increase of 2.86 billion patacas in expenses. On Tuesday, the AL also unanimously gave the green light to the budget for 2026, which foresees public expenditure of 113.5 billion patacas.

item.title: National security | Government will create risk alert system
item.description: Guardianship debates continue on the report on the Lines of Government Action for 2026. Yesterday the Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, guaranteed that in 2026 a risk alert system for national security will be created The Macau Government promised to create, in 2026, a risk warning system for national security and warned of “acts of interference and destruction” by “external forces”. The Secretary for Security set the goal for next year to implement “a system of monitoring and warning indicators of risks related to the defense of national security”. Chan Tsz King, who until December 2024 served as commissioner against Corruption, spoke during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action (LAG) for 2026, in the Legislative Assembly (AL). The former prosecutor promised to “remain highly vigilant in the face of the new and complex panorama” of international security and warned of “multiple factors of uncertainty that could compromise the security of the State”. Prevention matters Macau will “strictly prevent acts of interference and destruction [by] external forces”, guaranteed Chan, highlighting the importance of guaranteeing security in “major events”. Between the 9th and 21st of November, the regions of Macau, Hong Kong and Guangdong hosted the 15th edition of the National Games. On November 18, the Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, said that Macau received 2,480 people in delegations to the National Games. More than two million tourists passed through the city during the event. During yesterday's LAG debate, MP Lam Lon Wai defended the creation of “standardized security guidelines and procedures” for large events, including concerts. Chan Tsz King, who took office on October 16, promised to study Lam Lon Wai's suggestion, but stressed that authorities already have “specific [security] plans for different types of activity”. The secretary said that this year, the police “effectively prevented and investigated crimes against national security, deterring and combating anti-China and disruptive Macau individuals.” On July 31, local police authorities announced the arrest of former deputy and pro-democracy activist Au Kam San, a Portuguese citizen, in the first case under the region's national security law, which came into force in 2009 and whose scope was expanded in 2023. Last Thursday, the head of the European Union (EU) Delegation in Hong Kong and Macau wrote on social media that he had met with Macau's Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip. “I also expressed concern about political issues,” added Briton Harvey Rouse. But the EU representation declined to reveal whether the case of Au Kam San was mentioned at the meeting. Smuggling | Secretary highlights stability The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, stressed that the security situation in the territory is stable. “Between January and October 2025, the crime rate in Macau decreased compared to the same period in 2024”, he said, highlighting “the decreasing trend” in crimes such as “serious violence, theft, theft and computer fraud”, so “security in general remains stable and good”. However, Chan Tsz King highlighted the occurrence of several cases of smuggling, and in the first ten months of the year alone, 108 people “of school age” were intercepted, “seven times more than the same period” last year. The secretary also spoke of the occurrence, this year, of 126 cases of smuggling detected by the Customs Services. "We have established a communication mechanism with schools to reinforce compliance with the law. We will resort to a cooperation mechanism with the three parties [Hong Kong, Macau and Guangdong] to combat smuggling."

item.title: Literature | José Cordeiro, former teacher in Macau, launches book of chronicles
item.description: It is with the approval of the Writing Workshop that José Cordeiro, who was a physical education teacher in Macau for several years, makes his literary debut. After many chronicles written on the social network Facebook, the encouragement of friends and readers led him to edit “Ao Invés, Pois Claro”, where there is not even a lack of text about what it means to be Macanese “Ao Invés, Pois Claro” is the title of the first book by José Cordeiro, former resident of Macau and former physical education teacher in the territory. With the approval of Oficina da Escrita, the book has just been published in Portugal and is the result of a series of publications, on different topics, published on the social network Facebook. According to the description of the work, it is not only a “collection of chronicles”, but also “an invitation to freedom of thought, the exploration of doubt and knowledge”, the “celebration of diversity of opinions” that is carried out with a “relaxed approach”. "I don't have any specific guidelines for writing a chronicle, it depends on the mood of the moment. It's not something doctrinal, it doesn't intend to influence anything. It's a personal pleasure I have, playing with words", he told HM. Although José Cordeiro has always made physical activity his profession, the truth is that the connection to letters has always existed. "I've always liked playing with words. I only started writing more systematically recently. I selected some chronicles, like a literary kitchen, where you make soup and a lot of it ends up going to waste", he exemplified. The themes are diverse and “cover religion, politics, friendship, everything and nothing”. One of the chronicles refers to Macau and being Macanese, a community issue that José Cordeiro knows well. In “State of siege or state of mind”, Cordeiro talks about the existence of the community and says that today, 25 years later, Macanese live “both things”. “It could be a state of siege, because they are limited to a community, which is Portuguese in Chinese territory, and a state of mind, because many people don't live in Macau, but feel Macanese living abroad”, he stressed. “Ao Invés, Pois Claro” is a name that was born from the author’s desire to be “a little contrary”. "They say I'm stubborn, and so it seems to me [so]. I don't comment on the comments they make on my chronicles, and when I launch a chronicle it stops being mine at that moment, it becomes those who interpret it", he said. The power of social networks José Cordeiro believes that “a good way for a person to discipline their reasoning is to write” and writing “is a way of disciplining my intervention in the contacts I make with people”. It's "having a clear idea and, as a first principle, expressing it. It was in a wave of fun that I started doing things, writing. There were people who liked the texts and suggested that I publish them." "I say it's an album because, for me, it's something else. It's when you take a theme and carry it through to the end", highlighted José Cordeiro, who confesses that social networks "have allowed everything", even giving voice to new authors. "Sometimes I feel uncomfortable with what is done [on social media], but I am responsible for myself and what I do. I have no intention of indoctrinating or wanting to take anyone wherever. I am a simple citizen who likes to play in my literary kitchen, as I usually call it", he said. José Cordeiro is still preparing a launch session for the work, but it is already for sale on several online platforms.

item.title: Seoul | Bill presented to reduce US taxes
item.description: The ruling party in South Korea yesterday presented a bill to support South Korean investment commitments in the United States in exchange for reduced US tariffs. The bill provides for the creation of a special fund to finance the promised investment of 350 billion dollars to the United States, in exchange for the reduction of Washington's customs tariffs on vehicles and vehicle parts, among others, from 25 percent to 15 percent. Of the total amount, 150 billion dollars will be allocated to the North American naval sector, while the remaining 200 billion dollars will be invested, in annual tranches of up to 20 billion dollars, in various strategic US sectors. Although the legislative proposal will still be analyzed by the South Korean parliament, with the mere presentation of the document the tariff reduction will apply with retroactive effect to November 1st, in line with the bilateral memorandum of understanding signed in the middle of this month. The South Korean Ministry of Commerce sent a letter to the United States Secretary of Commerce, Howard Lutnick, informing that the proposed law to implement the memorandum of understanding has already been presented to the South Korean National Assembly and requesting that the retroactive reduction be applied accordingly.

item.title: TUI | Reduced sentence for man who tried to kill ex-wife
item.description: The Court of Final Instance (TUI) decided to reduce the prison sentence from 11 years and six months to eight years for a man convicted of attempted murder of his ex-wife, as “aggravating circumstances” had not been proven. The man was thus convicted of the attempted crime of simple homicide, in its attempted form, and decreed in the first instance by the Base Judicial Court (TJB), and not the crime of qualified homicide, also in its attempted form. The TUI understood that the man “only decided to attack B [his ex-wife] after having questioned her and realized that she would not pay the compensation” demanded by him. “Although it appears that the idea of ​​killing B [the woman] came to him since 2017, it was just a thought he had in his mind, and in the period from 2017 to April 2023, no action was taken to implement the idea of ​​killing”, it reads. The judges also considered, according to the ruling released yesterday, that “it is not clear that A [the accused man] acted coldly when attacking B [the woman]”, which is why the appeal presented by the man was upheld, considering the “excessive severity of the sentence determined” in the second instance. The case dates back to 2017, and the woman was already a victim of domestic violence during the relationship. The man “held a grudge” against the woman “for having reported his acts of domestic violence and other family disputes, giving him the idea of ​​killing her”. After the divorce, the man understood that his ex-wife had only obtained the Resident Identity Card (BIR) thanks to the marriage, so “he should pay her an amount as compensation”. The time of the crime The crime then began to enter into the plans of this man, who since April 2023 “kept a metal hammer in the box of his motorcycle”. On June 26 of that year, he stopped his motorcycle near his ex-wife's residence and “wandered around waiting for her”, then approached her and “demanded payment of the aforementioned compensation”. The woman ignored the man and walked away, and that was when the man “removed the metal hammer from the box of his motorcycle, ran after [her] and hit her in the head with the hammer”, and she “consequently fell to the ground”. The ruling describes that, “despite her fall, [the man] continued to hit the victim in the head with the hammer a total of five times, only stopping when he noticed that [the woman] was lying on the floor with decreased consciousness”. In the first instance, on July 31, 2024, the TJB convicted the man of committing a crime of attempted homicide and a crime of detention and use of a prohibited weapon, which, in legal terms, resulted in a sentence of eight years. Both the man and the Public Prosecutor's Office appealed to the second instance, which increased the sentence to 11 years and six months for the crime of attempted qualified homicide, crime of detention and use of a prohibited weapon. On February 14 of this year, the TUI accepted the convict's appeal and sent the case again to the Court of Second Instance (TSI), which repeated the trial and maintained the sentence of 11 years and six months in prison, but the man did not accept the decision and requested a new appeal, claiming that the TSI “did not fulfill its obligation to carry out a new trial, incurring an error in interpreting and applying the law”, determining “an excessively severe penalty”. The attacker has now managed to see his sentence reduced.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Xiao Yi (508-555), Emperor Yuan of Liang (552-555), had a scroll of paintings made documenting, through the portraits of the respective ambassadors, the number of vassal states that in the four directions were tributaries of his kingdom. Thus showing how diverse the faces and clothing of those who lived beyond the borders were. With the passage of time and unforeseen events caused by the movements of the imperial courts, this scroll would have become damaged, but during the brief Southern Tang dynasty (937-976) its third and last emperor Li Yu (r. 961-976), who cultivated the arts of the brush while neglecting the government of the kingdom, ordered that a copy be made, in ink only. The use of copying as a method would allow the continuity over time of ideas and perceptions, countering the fragility – of the limits of the deterioration of the supports and of the authors' own lives. The court painter in Jiankang (present-day Nanjing, Jiangsu) chosen to make this Copy of foreign guests entering the court of Emperor Yuan of Liang (Liang Yuandi fanke ruchao tu, at the National Palace Museum, in Taipei) are attributed two other paintings that allude in different ways to circulation and crossing boundaries. In the vertical scroll in ink and color on silk attributed to him, Pond of lotuses and water birds, at the Tokyo National Museum, the natural cycle of the lotus flower is depicted, from the bud to the flower to the withering of the leaves and flowers. In another vertical scroll called Night Hunter returning home on a snowy night (ink and color on silk, 114 x 61 cm, at the Frankfurt Museum of Applied Art, Angewandte Kunst, Frankfurt) we see the figure of a man with an angry appearance, to express powerful, in exquisite clothes to say that he is noble, with an unusual weapon, a trident, from which hang two dead animals that could be two ermines. He comes walking in the snow under a cliff accompanied by a dog whose collar looks like a necklace. In fact, these figures may be telling another story. Gu Deqian is said to have portrayed in this painting the recognizable figure of popular religion and Daoism called Erlang Shen, the «Divinity of the second boy» with his blue immortal's robes, a caregiver and trustworthy protector, with his sanchaji trident or sanjian liangren qiang, a «three-pronged double-bladed spear» that Manchu shamans used to defeat evil spirits who wanted to cross the border of the other World. Those, like stoats (mustela erminea), were seen as wanderers capable of stealing and replacing people's souls. Erlang shen can be seen in several representations, as here, accompanied by the black dog xiaotian quan, the “howling celestial dog”. The snow will melt but there will be no floods because Erlang shen will not allow it, in the cold of the night the fearsome hunter is after all a figure of stillness.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: Macau gaming concessionaire SJM Resorts announced yesterday that the Kam Pek Paradise 'satellite casino', with almost 600 employees, will close on December 1st. SJM said that Kam Pek Parasise “will officially cease operations at 23:59 (Monday, December 1st), thus becoming the seventh ‘satellite casino’ in the region to close its doors. In a statement, SJM, founded by gaming tycoon Stanley Ho Hung Sun (1921-2020), highlighted that all local employees directly hired by the company have guaranteed employment. SJM explained that staff with resident status in Macau will be “transferred to other company casinos to perform gaming-related functions, according to operational needs”. Local employees who were not hired directly by SJM Resorts “are invited to apply for related vacancies” within the group, “with priority for hiring” and with conditions equal to those they had. Also yesterday, the Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Department (DICJ) assured that it will “strictly supervise, on site, the closure procedures” of Kam Pek Paradise. With regard to the 584 casino employees, the DICJ assured, in a press release, that it will maintain communication with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs, to ensure compliance with the guarantees given by the SJM, namely “the relocation of all aforementioned workers”. SJM highlighted that “all tables and gaming machines currently operating on site will be transferred to other company casinos”.

item.title: José Simões Morais
item.description: In Macau, most commercial establishments have the image of Kuan Tai (Guan Di in Mandarin), who appears with a strong body, red face, long black beard and dressed as a military officer, holding a spear in his right hand. As a person, he is known as Guan Yu and is related to the fall of the Han dynasty and the struggles to establish the Shu kingdom, in the period that preceded the Three Kingdoms. With the name Chang Sheng (长生), he was born in Xiezhou (today Yuncheng, Shanxi province), on the 24th day of the sixth lunar month in the 60s of the 2nd century. As an episode from his youth, it is said that one day a nobleman forcibly wanted to possess a girl and Guan Yu, outraged, killed him. Pursued by the authorities, he had to flee and according to legend, in order not to be recognized, Guanyin (known in Macau as Kun Iam) changed the color of his face to red. Another story says that a rural owner with a lot of power, in order to force everyone to buy water from him, polluted the other sources in the region. Saturated with such infamy, Guan Yu one day killed him and had to flee the city. During this flight, to cross the border (guan), he took the name Guan Yu. In the late Eastern Han dynasty (25-220), the decadent court in Luoyang was dominated by eunuchs and generals. Guan Yu was wandering as a street vendor in Zhuo Municipality (now Hebei Province) when he met Liu Bei and Zhang Fei. The three swore an oath in the Peach Garden to become brothers in arms, with Guan Yu and Zhang Fei vowing to help Liu Bei, linked to the royal house of Han, in his armed uprising to establish the Shu-Han kingdom. At that time there were two other different factions that divided the country and thus in the North, the Wei army led by Cao Cao dominated, in the East and South the Wu forces and in the West, the Shu. There were constant battles between them. Guan Yu, an avid reader of the Classic “Spring-Autumn Annals” (Chunqiu jing) who always accompanied him, had commanded the Shu garrison in Jingzhou for 10 years. In the year 219/220, while engaged in a battle outside the wall against the Wei forces, he was caught in a surprise attack by the Wu army, which was more or less allied with the Shu. The Wu conquered the city and killed Guan Yu, cutting off his head and, as a proof of friendship, handing it over to Cao Cao. Halfway there they learned that the Wei had made a peace agreement with the Shu and so the head was abandoned near Luoyang. The process of his deification was long. Although he was only God of War during the Ming period, when in 1578 Emperor Wan Li gave him the title of Emperor Guan (Guan Di), already in the Sui dynasty he had a temple dedicated to him in the place where he was buried, with the titles being given by all the following dynasties. During his life, Guan Yu had the position of Military Officer (Hou). In the Song dynasty he took the place of King (Wang). Due to his loyalty, honesty, piety, benevolence, sense of justice and courage, he became very popular due to the book San Guo Yan Yi, written at the beginning of the Ming dynasty. In this dynasty he was promoted to Emperor (Di) and then, in 1614, to Sage (Sheng) or Military Saint (Wu Di). As a Being so perfect, all professions want him as their patron and thus he is venerated as the God of War, Literature, Wealth and patron of Martial Arts. In Macau, Guan Di is known as Kuan Tai and the Sam Kai Wui Kun temple, located on Rua Sul of the S. Domingos market, is dedicated to him. There, the image of the God is entirely golden, with no objects in his hands and is accompanied on his left by Chau Chong and on the other side by Kuan Peng. His birthday falls on the 24th of the sixth lunar month, although no festivities are officially held in his honor. 灶神 Zao Shen – the god of the Stove The god of the Stove, known in Macau as Tchôu-Sân (in Mandarin Zao Shen), is the most important of the domestic deities and twice a month (during the New Moon and the Full Moon) he received offerings, despite his birthday only being celebrated on the third day of the eighth Moon. However, the most important ceremonies performed to this god are those that occur before the week-long journey, when the god leaves home and goes to Heaven to perform the annual report to the Jade Emperor about the family of the residence where he is placed. And that is why this god, also known as the god of the Kitchen, as for simplification he came to be called the god of the Kitchen Chimney, has great power over the lives of the people who form the household. It is in the last week of the lunar year that he ascends to Heaven to meet with the Jade Emperor, where he reports to him the events that took place in the room in his charge, returning on the first day of the year, where he is placed again in the kitchen, behind the stove. On the eve of the trip, on the twenty-third day of the last lunar month, the inhabitants of the house offer sacrifices to this deity, filling him with sweets so that he only tells good things to the Jade Emperor. In a ceremony performed only by men, the god of Stove leaves transported on a horse and to make the journey easy and pleasant, one of the male beings in the house takes a candle and burns the image of the god so that it can more easily ascend through smoke to Heaven. Before being named by the Jade Emperor as God of the Stove, or of the Kitchen, he was a husband who, having spent all his money gambling and selling his wife, years later, while begging on the streets, arrived at his former wife's house. She, recognizing him and taking pity on him, takes him to the kitchen where she gives him something to eat. But her current husband arrives and so she doesn't see him, she hides him in the fireplace. When the maid lights the fire, so as not to compromise the charitable woman, she stays there. The Jade Emperor, seeing his sacrifice, named him the god of the Stove, also known as the god of the Kitchen, or the god of the Home. There are other versions of both how the man lost the money and how his ex-wife supported him. She, without being recognized by her ex-husband, gave him some cakes and placed a coin in each one. The man, on the way, met another beggar, who, upon seeing the bag with cakes, asked him for one. He discovered the coin in the middle of the cake and, realizing that the other didn't know about the filling, proposed keeping them all, which he managed in exchange for a small amount. When he later found out what he had done, realizing his bad luck, he decided to commit suicide. The Jade Emperor, seeing his kindness, named him god of the Kitchen. The celebration of this deity's journey to Heaven began in summer, but during the Han dynasty it moved to winter and during the Ming dynasty it was celebrated by the people on the 24th, with sacrifices taking place the day before. Zao Shen is represented in an image containing only his figure, or associated with his consort, or even just characters, which is placed on the first day of the lunar year in the kitchen behind the stove.

item.title: November 25th | Manuel Geraldes remembers “moment of betrayal”
item.description: Portugal marked the 50th anniversary of November 25, 1975 yesterday with a military parade and a solemn session in the Assembly of the Republic, amidst controversies and political readings from right to left. Manuel Geraldes, a former soldier based in Macau, remembers the moment he was arrested at RTP For Manuel Geraldes, if happiness had a date it would be April 25, 1974, along with the day his daughter was born. But it was in connection with the 50th anniversary of November 25, 1975, an attempted coup d'état and one of the stages of the revolutionary process that began with the overthrow of the dictatorship in Portugal on April 25, 1974, that we spoke with the former soldier. Based in Macau since the 1980s, Manuel Geraldes was arrested at RTP on November 25, 1975, but, as one of the youngest captains of April, he was involved in the revolution since its beginning, starting with the so-called captains' movement in 1973. To HM, he remembers the 25th of November as “a very sad moment, of betrayal by comrades, revolt, a horrible moment, especially compared to one of the happiest days of my life, together with the birth of my daughter, which was the 25th of April”, taking into account the military plans planned for that day, which took a different turn. Manuel Geraldes worked at RTP when the station was controlled by one of the military factions that carried out the 25th of November. Control of RTP, at the Lumiar studios in Lisbon, included the intervention of figures such as Manuel Duran Clemente, then linked to the military extreme left of the 5th Division. "When we talk about the 25th of November we have to talk about a day of betrayal. Those who were betrayed were the soldiers who remained faithful to their ideas of the 25th of April and who swore to comply with it, and which we were fulfilling. There was a group of soldiers who, forgetting their condition, and I'm talking more about permanent staff officers, made that day of shame for any self-respecting officer." Manuel Geraldes had been at RTP for about a year and was “caught in that trap”. I went to meet my comrades at the television news management office and it was there that we were caught by Captain Duran Clemente”, he tells HM. “I can talk about those who were closest to me, and who were at RTP that day”, he began by saying. "Those who were on the 25th of April and arrested me, as they arrested six other officers, all of them 'dangerous fascists, reactionaries'. Also arrested that day was a man who was a great revolutionary, and who, still as a student at the military academy, studying at Técnico, committed the noble gesture of leaving the armed forces of the fascist regime to emigrate to northern Europe. The 'powerful' Marques, who had been in the Beja coup, and who was arrested, and managed to go into exile in Brazil. Captain Canavilhas, a ‘dangerous’ man who had been on the 25th of April and who was there providing a service to the Republic at RTP as an electrical engineer.” Duran Clemente appeared at RTP's facilities to control broadcasts, prohibit the dissemination of information from the Presidency of the Republic, since Costa Gomes was President at the time, and let messages from rebels linked to a faction of the movement pass through. The station's board of directors was detained for several hours. His live images are known on RTP, reading a statement, when he was suddenly interrupted and replaced in the broadcast by the film “The Man from the Diner’s Club”. This is because the winning faction of the 25 de Novembro movement had taken control of events from the RTP studios in Porto. Speaking to the newspaper Público, Duran Clemente also speaks of November 25th as “a betrayal of April 25th, in the way it has been interpreted and was interpreted, to the extent that it interrupted the natural course of a revolution that is never a natural path”. Duran Clemente also speaks, in the same interview, of the “fantasy story of a civil war” that many believe was about to happen in Portugal on that date. He also says “he did not commit any crime”. For Manuel Geraldes, these moments of detention “were indescribable, unbelievable, forgettable”. When he left the RTP studios, Manuel Geraldes went home to his wife, “trying to rest and try to forget the enormous sadness that was that scene”, with “the soldiers he had commanded on April 25, 1974, observing that absurd arrest that Duran Clemente made of us”. The culmination of tensions The 25th of November was an attempted coup d'état in which military personnel linked to the extreme left took several strategic points, especially in Lisbon, which led the country to enter a state of siege. But the moderates won and the country entered a calmer phase, especially after the new Constitution of 1976. It was a culmination of the so-called “Hot Summer”, or the months of the PREC – Revolutionary Period in Progress, marked by nationalizations of banks and companies, the Agrarian Reform process, organization of workers committees, attacks on the headquarters of the Portuguese Communist Party and various actions connoted with both the extreme left and the far right. Manuel Geraldes recalls that “the situation was complex and was not exactly what we had imagined” with the 25th of April. “We had designed other scenarios than that, but with great camaraderie.” Even so, the former soldier highlights the “stability and credibility” that Portugal gained after November 25, 1975. However, he does not agree with the fact that the Portuguese authorities are currently celebrating this date. "There is definitely a political component and, for me, it makes absolutely no sense. We shouldn't forget the past to correct any mistakes that were made, but celebrating a sad day makes no sense at all. We must remember." Regarding the important and decisive figures in resolving the 25th of November, Manuel Geraldes highlights “general Costa Gomes, who experienced such vast violence, Sousa e Castro and others who had consensus and managed to bring the vast majority of the armed forces to reason”. Mário Soares, as leader of the Socialist Party, “also had [importance]” to stop the movement, especially because “he had positions close to the so-called ‘Group of Nine’, the moderate members of the Coordinating Commission of the Armed Forces Movement”. Manuel Geraldes also remembers a day when the factions were ruled by “military against military”, and when “the homeland was put at risk”, in a scenario “very, very close to civil war”. Yesterday morning, a military ceremony took place promoted by the Armed Forces, at Praça do Comércio, in Lisbon, presided over by the President of the Republic, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. There was also a formal session in the Assembly of the Republic. Vasco Lourenço: “A coup d’état was not on the ground” In addition to the official ceremonies of the 25th of November 1975, there have been several exhibitions, lectures and conferences that celebrate all stages of the revolution of the 25th of April 1974. One of them took place on Tuesday, the seminar “25th of November – 50 years later”, at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, where one of the central figures of the 25th of November and the entire April revolution, Vasco Lourenço, remembered the day. "It is clear that, after all this time, we cannot say that a coup d'état was on the ground. But I challenge anyone who is capable of saying that, at that time, given what was happening, we did not look at it as if a coup d'état were actually taking place." After several military movements, in which the paratrooper forces retreated, the episodes of November 25th resulted in three deaths, all military personnel, “at the beginning of November 27th”, recalled Vasco Lourenço. The role of women Another figure who participated in the debate was doctor Isabel do Carmo, who at the time of November 25th was linked to the COPCON group – Continent Operational Command, led by the now deceased Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho. Isabel do Carmo argued that “what happened after the 25th of April was the existence of a space of people, organizations and political protagonists, in which there were clearly two trends”, marked by “those who wanted to lead a revolutionary movement to de facto socialism, and those who wanted a liberal democracy with an economy regulated by a market”. "The 25th of April was, and for many people of my generation, the best times of my life. I hear many people say this, particularly women, who until then were discreet. What happened after [the 25th of April] were the public sessions, freedom of the press, the total change in the environment in schools, there was a great transformation in the country", concluded Isabel do Carmo.

item.title: Timorese women victims of sexual violence during the war demand an end to discrimination
item.description: Reporting by Domingos Freitas, from the Lusa agency The Pirilampo association, which represents women victims of sexual violence between 1974 and 1999, demands that the Timorese State supports them, after years of discrimination by society and their families. "We continue to fight alone because we were victims in the past, not of our own free will. We have suffered the consequences of this country's politics since 1974, because we wanted self-determination. Because of these political decisions, we, women, were the target of many sexual violations", Maria Isabel da Silva, president of Pirilampo, told Lusa, as part of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence and Indonesian occupation. Maria Isabel da Silva accused the Timorese State of not having granted them recognition that could help them recover their courage and dignity. "We created Pirilampo because we know that we are not minor survivors. We are survivors of sexual violence that occurred during the war, between 1974 and 1999. We want to recover dignity, because many face stigma in their communities and even within their own families", explained Maria Isabel da Silva. The president of Pirilampo explained that the organization's mission is to support women survivors of sexual violence through social, legal and economic assistance so that they become strong and independent citizens. The association also defends the rights of victims and survivors who remain without a voice, so that they can obtain recognition and attention from the State or Government. Maria Isabel da Silva clarified that Pirilampo's vision is to contribute to ensuring that Timorese society never again allows anyone to be a victim of serious human rights violations, especially sexual violence, including harassment, abuse, rape or forced marriage. The president of Pirilampo also regretted that cultural aspects discriminate against women who became pregnant or had children by unidentified men. "Sometimes they are considered prostitutes, remnants of the Indonesian military. These are insults that have been directed at us for a long time," he said. With support from the Chega Ba Ita Association (ACBIT) and Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR), several victims participated in various activities and, on October 22, 2022, these organizations helped them create the Klibur Survivor Feto Firefly 1974-1999, to alleviate the suffering and difficulties faced. Pirilampo has already registered 455 women survivors of sexual violence, of which 87 gave birth to children resulting from these violations. To this day, those children, often called “war children”, face a very difficult life, due to discrimination by their families, society and, above all, in the public administration. "They call them children of unknown fathers, children of bush men, of militia. This greatly affects their self-esteem and many refuse to go to school", warned the president. Maria Isabel Silva explains that many of these young people are also unable to obtain basic documents, such as baptism certificates from the Church or State documents. They live in remote areas, depend on agriculture and do not have adequate access to health and education. The president called on the Government to pay attention and recognize these people like any other citizen, so that their children can also live in freedom and equality. "We are alive. We don't ask for anything, we don't ask for money. The money from the State is not enough to pay for our dignity. We lost our bodies, we carry pain and trauma. We just want to recover our complete being. We don't ask for money", said an emotional Maria Isabel Silva. There is still discrimination Fernanda Guterres and Maria Gusmão were born after their mothers were raped by Indonesian soldiers during the occupation of Timor-Leste, and to this day they continue to face discrimination in their country. The two carry the stigma of being “war children”, a name given to people who were born to women who were raped between 1974 and 1999, during the conflict between various Timorese factions and during the Indonesian occupation. "I don't feel free, because I continue to face discrimination from society. Colleagues say words to me that hurt me, and I myself am afraid of making friends because of the harsh words they say to me", Fernanda Guterres, who works at the non-governmental organization ACBIT, which supports, with Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR), the "children of war" and women victims of sexual violence during the occupation to overcome the difficulties and traumas that marked their lives, told Lusa. “I only feel a little freedom when I participate in oratory sessions or in training given by the sisters, which encourage young people to face reality”, he highlighted. The report by the Commission for Reception, Truth and Reconciliation (CAVR), released 20 years ago, and which collected testimonies from hundreds of victims of sexual violence, states that the majority was committed by the Indonesian occupation forces. "We are Children of War because our mothers were forced and impregnated by other men during the occupation. Otherwise, the invaders would have killed the entire family. To save their own lives, many Timorese women suffered sexual violence", explained Fernanda Guterres. As a consequence of this forced rape, “war children” continue to be targets of insults and stigma. “You have no father”, “you are the son of the enemy” or “son of a militia”, are some of the insults that those women continue to hear. When she was little, Fernanda Guterres' mother told her that her father was alive, but she never met him. She later discovered that it didn't exist, but her mother never explicitly admitted it. "I asked about my mother and father many times. My mother always said 'your father is there', and said not to believe if someone said otherwise. But I never met him. In the end, I realized that I didn't have a father", he said. Fernanda Guterres also remembers, with sadness, the attempts of sexual violence by members of the community, solely due to her mother's past. "The family and also some neighbors tried to abuse me. When I was an adult, I stopped keeping quiet and asked my family to face anyone who tried to harm me", said the 28-year-old. Today, Fernanda has her own family, with three children, and said she has found a partner who fully supports her. "I met my husband thanks to God's plan. He knew about my mother's past and his whole family knew too, but they never discriminated against me. They always welcomed me. My husband supports me, gives me courage. The past is behind us. Now we look to the future and our children. That's what gives me strength", she stated. "We live a simple life. We don't have formal jobs, but we always maintain respect and mutual understanding. When a problem arises at home, we talk and look for a solution together", he said. Fernanda Guterres managed to obtain documents from the Church or State, thanks to the support of people who helped her regularize everything. Maria Gusmão also acknowledged that her mother was a victim of sexual violence by Indonesian soldiers. "When I was little, in primary school and pre-secondary school, I suffered discrimination due to the conflict my mother faced. They said I was the daughter of the militia, the daughter of the enemy. I heard this with my own ears", said the young woman from Covalima. He also remembers that some members of his community even banned children from playing with him. Later, at university and even within his family, he continued to face discrimination. Despite this, Maria Robinson appealed to other young women not to lose their will to fight, nor their hope, even in the face of discrimination, highlighting that the State must dignify women who have been victims of sexual violence and also their children. Maria Robinson was able to obtain documents because her stepfather agreed to put her name on the birth certificates. When asked about her feeling of freedom, she replied that she just feels “a little free”, highlighting that she still faces discrimination, stigma and injustice today. “From the family, to society, to the community and even to our own State”, said the 25-year-old. Maria Robinson recently completed her degree at the University of Peace (UNPAZ) and also works at the non-governmental organization ACBIT. On November 28, Timor-Leste marks 50 years since the unilateral declaration of independence and Indonesian occupation, on December 7, 1975. The restoration of independence took place on May 20, 2002, after a referendum for self-determination was held on August 30, 1999.

item.title: LAG | Government restricts the use of “Western” devices because they represent a “risk”
item.description: The Government is betting on Chinese electronic devices, to avoid risks associated with equipment coming from countries with a “hostile stance” towards China. Wong Sio Chak revealed that all public servants, including Portuguese, will take an oath of loyalty to China and Macao by the end of the year The Government revealed on Friday that the Public Administration is giving priority to Chinese electronic devices, because those coming from Western countries “with a hostile stance towards China” represent “a risk”. “Instructions have already been issued by the DSAFP [Directorate of Administration and Public Function Services], especially for critical infrastructures,” said the Macau Secretary for Administration and Justice. “We considered, as a priority, the use of devices from our country” in RAM’s government services and departments, highlighted Wong Sio Chak. The leader admitted to the Legislative Assembly that “there is a risk” in the supply of electronic telecommunications devices. “It is a very sensitive issue and one in which there is also a fragility”, said Wong, pointing the finger at “Western countries, especially some with a hostile stance towards China”. However, the secretary highlighted, during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action for 2026 in the area of ​​Administration and Justice, that the limitations only apply to the public administration of Macau. "We have an open market and we will not restrict the private sector to use foreign devices. Entities and the private sector have the freedom to choose these devices", explained Wong. On October 19, the Central Government accused the United States of carrying out a cyber-attack against the National Time Service Center (NTSC), responsible for maintaining the accuracy of the country's official time. The Chinese Ministry of State Security said the “systematic and long-planned” attack began in 2022, through a vulnerability in the SMS (short message) service of a “foreign brand” of mobile phones. The vulnerability made it possible to “covertly attack and gain control of the cell phones of several NTSC employees and steal confidential data stored on them”, said the ministry. Faithful and loyal Another highlight of Wong Sio Chak's presentation was the oath of loyalty to China and the Macao SAR that all public servants, including those of Portuguese nationality, will have to take by the end of the year. The oath is part of a review of the statutes of management and leadership staff and Public Administration workers, which came into force on 1 November. The two revised laws determine that workers already in office have 90 days to take the oath, with refusal automatically implying the annulment of the appointment to the position or dismissal. But the Secretary for Administration and Justice said he believes the process will be completed sooner and that “all public service workers will take the oath by the end of this year”. Wong Sio Chak, who took office on October 16, defended during the presentation of the Governing Action Lines for 2026 that the review “improved the management and accountability regime of management and leadership staff”. On November 1st, 264 directors of public entities and services took an oath in a ceremony, declaring that “they will dedicate themselves with all loyalty to the Macau Special Administrative Region [SAR] of the People's Republic of China”. In a speech given during the ceremony, the Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, asked civil service leaders to “firmly safeguard the full governance power of the Chinese Central Government”. In December 2024, the Legislative Assembly approved, unanimously and without any debate, the law that provides that public servants in Macau can be dismissed if they carry out “acts contrary” to their oath. A month earlier, when presenting the proposal, the then Executive Council spokesman, André Cheong, warned that public servants could be fired due to private conversations or comments published on social media. The oath will be mandatory for all public officials, including Portuguese ones, but it can be taken in Portuguese, one of Macau's two official languages, along with Chinese. According to the most recent Public Administration Human Resources Report, in 2023 the region had 34,311 public employees. The document does not mention how many have Portuguese nationality, only mentioning that 257 were born in Portugal. The two proposals also oblige public servants to take the oath in a “sincere and solemn” manner. The sincerity of the oath will be assessed by the hierarchical superior and any dismissal may be appealed to the courts. Every head The Government wants to launch, at the beginning of 2026, negotiations with Portugal on an agreement for the reciprocal recognition of civil and commercial judgments. Macau's Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak, said that he intends to “strengthen judicial cooperation abroad and further expand legal exchange”. According to the LAG report, Macau wants, from the first quarter of 2026, to start negotiating an “agreement on the reciprocal confirmation and enforcement of judicial decisions in civil and commercial matters” with Portugal. However, the document does not mention any date for the conclusion of negotiations and the eventual signing of a final agreement. Macau and Portugal signed an agreement in 2019 regarding the surrender of fugitive offenders, whose criminal legality was called into question by the Portuguese Bar Association. The protocol is not in force, as it was not voted on in the Assembly of the Republic. The Macau LAG report also reveals plans to conclude, by the end of 2026, three agreements with Angola for the transfer of convicted people, the delivery of fugitive offenders and mutual legal assistance in criminal cases. These three agreements with Angola have been mentioned in the Macau LAG since November 2023, and that report pointed to the end of 2024 as a target for concluding the negotiations. Angola and mainland China signed an extradition treaty in 2006, which was only approved by the Angolan Parliament in 2011, and was ratified by the Government of Luanda two years later. During the discussion in the Angolan Parliament, the then Angolan deputy minister of Justice, João Monteiro, defended the importance of the agreement due to the large migratory movement between the two countries. At the time, authorities estimated that close to 50,000 Chinese lived in Angola, working mainly in construction, in reconstruction projects financed largely by loans granted by China. João Monteiro guaranteed that the two States agreed that extradition requests cannot include crimes of a political or military nature. Macau Simplex Wong Sio Chak reiterated to the deputies an old promise from the Administration and Justice department: administrative simplification. The government priority will aim to speed up processes and licenses, for example, for commercial establishments. In response to a question from Deputy Si Ka Lon, the Secretary for Administration and Justice said that, “as long as there are no major works”, a food and beverage establishment can obtain a license to operate in two days, upon presentation of all the required documents. The government official stressed that behind the flexibility of the administration machine are the concepts of “simplifying, decentralizing and optimizing”. Get to work The Secretary for Administration and Justice stated in the Legislative Assembly that the Government will continue efforts to implement the quota system for Public Service workers and reorganize some careers, eliminating those that are outdated and promoting mobility. Wong Sio Chak highlighted that since the launch of the quota management system in the Administration, in 2020, the number of public servants has increased, and that before changing the rules for progression or access between careers in the administrative machinery, the Government will listen to workers.

item.title: East Timor | April Revolution left “difficult memories”
item.description: Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, researcher at the University of Coimbra, addresses, in a study, the experiences of the Timorese during the period of the 25th of April Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, a researcher at the Center for Social Sciences at the University of Coimbra, considered that the April revolution in Timor-Leste left “difficult memories” and that reconciliation is fundamental for “national cohesion”. “When we talk about the 25th of April in Timor, we know that we are talking about difficult memories that have left marks to this day due to the internal conflict and the violation of human rights during the occupation”, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, who is currently carrying out a study on that period in the country, told Lusa. Marisa Ramos Gonçalves is also a member of the International Advisory Board of the National Chega Center (in Timor-Leste), which, among other activities, documents the history of the conflict in Timor-Leste between 1974 and 1999. The researcher explained to Lusa that the objective is to understand the other side of the story “based on the experiences of the Timorese of the 25th of April and this period of transition, which gives rise to a proclamation of independence, but which is very short compared to the occupation”. “This collective memory of the Timorese is inseparable, both from the internal conflict and from the human tragedy that is the Indonesian invasion and occupation”, highlighted Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. The unilateral proclamation of Timor-Leste's independence, on November 28, 1975, came after a period marked by clashes between the East Timorese and already under the shadow of the possibility of occupation of the territory by Indonesia, which came to fruition on December 7, 1975. Asked about reconciliation between East Timorese, the researcher said that the “issue has been on the table”. "It is necessary to achieve reconciliation between Timorese who were on opposite sides during the civil conflict with different options for the future of Timor. At the time, UDT wanted an association with Portugal for a few more years before independence, Fretilin wanted immediate independence, and Apodeti, which wanted integration into Indonesia and they are all Timorese", he stated. According to Marisa Gonçalves, the National Chega Center wants “this to start being on the table, because it has not been easy until now for Timorese who suffered torture or were persecuted during the period of internal conflict to speak openly”. "But we are already beginning to see this possibility when talking about violence and torture, which existed for a very short period in 1975, but which left strong marks. There is also a reconciliation at the level of political leadership that is yet to be achieved and I think this is also complicated. It is a reconciliation of the entire society", stated Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. Larger opening Considering reconciliation between Timorese people as fundamental for social cohesion, the researcher highlights, on the other hand, that the new generations formed in the Indonesian period and the younger ones “are completely prepared for this reconciliation”. “They are not so tied to previous conflicts and they really want to reconcile and, therefore, I think they are already looking at that future, they already think that all people are part of the Timorese Nation, including the Timorese who are in West Timor”, where there is a community of around 80,000 people, he highlighted. "It is also important that the older generation reconciles, especially because it is still a generation, the so-called generation of 75, that continues in power. It would also be interesting for them to take the initiative to get closer", he added. Regarding the study she is carrying out, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves said that there is a lack of historical research in Timor-Leste and that it is good to understand the expectations that people had not only in relation to the 25th of April, but also in relation to the political transition. “It means knowing the narratives, the experiences, the memories of Timorese people of various geographic origins, professional occupations and party affiliations about the same historical moment”, he explained, highlighting that reconciliation is also achieved through the writing of history.

item.title: Decolonization in Timor-Leste left deep traumas in the Portuguese military, argues researcher
item.description: The researcher at the Institute of Contemporary History at Universidade Nova Zélia Pereira stated that the decolonization process in Timor-Leste left deep traumas in the Portuguese military, leading many to silence during the period of Indonesian occupation. “The decolonization process in Timor, in addition to the trauma of the Indonesian invasion for the Timorese themselves, left profound traumas for the Portuguese military, personal and psychological traumas, consequences for their professional careers, most of them ended up abandoning military life, because they were successively passed over for promotions,” the researcher told Lusa. “Lemos Pires, when he was promoted to general, there was an internal campaign against him,” he said. General Mário Lemos Pires was the last governor of Portuguese Timor (between November 8, 1974 and November 27, 1975). Zélia Pereira is coordinating, together with Pedro Aires de Oliveira, professor of History at the Faculty of Social and Human Sciences at Universidade Nova, the reissue of the report prepared by the commission for the analysis and clarification of the decolonization process of Timor-Leste, created by former President Ramalho Eanes, which will include declassified testimonies from military and civilian personnel heard in 1975 and 1976. The project is being financed by the Foundation for Science and Technology, with the support of the commission for the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the 25th of April, as part of a competition for exploratory projects. "It is such a huge trauma that throughout the entire period of Indonesian occupation, apart from Lemos Pires, no other soldier wanted to speak. After the referendum, some memoirs began to be published and only now more recently have they started to agree to do some interviews", explained the researcher. According to Zélia Pereira, the testimonies given in 1976, with the “very fresh memory” and the “very vivid trauma” will allow access to a very “detailed, very interesting” set of information. The researcher also hopes that these testimonies will help the Timorese to “better understand a period that was very traumatic for them”. “We need to understand the following, even today books continue to be published, articles that replicate all the accusations made in 1975. In doctoral and master's theses, because they are based on books published in the 70s, 80s, 2000s, up until the present and which still today are based on ideas and assumptions, which are not all 100% wrong, but which need to have other interpretations”, he highlighted. History, said Zélia Pereira, is about placing several contexts under analysis simultaneously, because no one owns the truth. “What we want is for this to open up other perspectives, other research perspectives, and heal hurts, reconcile people with their past, regardless of whether they made decisions that didn’t turn out to be the right ones,” he added. Timor-Leste became independent from Portugal on November 28, 1975, but nine days later, on December 7, it was occupied by Indonesia.

item.title: Venezuela | Maduro declares that country will never be defeated
item.description: The President of Venezuela declared yesterday that the country will never be defeated and that the Venezuelan people will respond to what he considered to be a psychological war orchestrated by the United States. Speaking to the official Venezuelan television station VTV, Nicolás Maduro stated that the authorities and people of Venezuela will respond with work and achievements to the “psychological war”, referring to the North American Administration as “media scoundrels” from Miami. “How do you say ‘imbecile’ in English?” asked Maduro, warning those “who want to do harm” will never be able to defeat Venezuela. Washington has intensified military operations off Venezuela in recent days, reiterating accusations against Maduro that he promotes drug trafficking. The North American head of state, Donald Trump, also authorized new attacks against vessels, allegedly belonging to drug trafficking networks, near the Venezuelan coast. Maduro added that Venezuelan security forces have seized 63 tons of drugs since the beginning of the year. On the other hand, the Venezuelan leader also denounced the attempt to enter Venezuela by two planes linked to drug trafficking. In the same speech, Maduro declared that Venezuela and Russia are making progress in military cooperation, which he described as peaceful and fruitful. Daily contact Asked about contacts between Caracas and Moscow in the context of “threats” from the United States, Maduro stated that the government maintains daily communication with Russian President Vladimir Putin on “several developing issues”, including military matters. On Sunday, the Russian Presidency admitted having maintained contacts with Venezuela regarding a possible request for help from Maduro to Putin. At the same time, the People's Republic of China stated that there is normal cooperation between Beijing and Caracas. The North American newspaper Washington Post reported that the Venezuelan President asked Russia, China and Iran for help to defend the country from pressure from the United States. For Beijing, this is cooperation between sovereign states and is not directed against third parties. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said at a press conference that China supports strengthening international cooperation to combat “transnational crime” and opposes the use or threat of such force in international relations.

item.title: Pop Mart, fabricante de Labubu, cai 10,8% em Hong Kong entre dúvidas sobre crescimento
