item.description: Shares in Pop Mart, the Chinese company responsible for the global phenomenon of Labubu figures, sank 10.8% this Thursday, the biggest drop since April, in a new episode of volatility that contrasts with the good sales results released the day before. The devaluation reflects investors' growing caution regarding the possibility of a slowdown in the company's growth, after several quarters driven by the popularity of its collectible products. On Wednesday, Pop Mart shares rose 4.23% on the Hong Kong stock exchange, despite the negative tone of the market, following the announcement that revenue in the third quarter increased between 245% and 250%, driven by Labubu's virality on social media and the company's international expansion. According to data provided by the company, domestic sales grew 190%, while international sales soared 370%, highlighted by increases of 175% in the Asia-Pacific region, more than 740% in Europe and almost 1,270% in the United States. The strong drop recorded today is largely attributed to profit taking, after appreciation of more than 186% since the beginning of the year, and uncertainty about the sustainability of the current growth rate. The stock fell 8.1% on Tuesday, its worst performance since April, weighed down by fears of a slowdown in sales after months of euphoria. The preliminary release of results helped to temporarily dispel these concerns, but the absence of an official date for the presentation of the accounts maintains uncertainty regarding the company's future evolution. Executive chairman and founder Wang Ning expressed confidence in the long-term resilience of the Labubu character, arguing that cultural icons continue to generate revenue even after peak popularity. According to the Bloomberg agency, the explosion in demand forced the company itself to revise its internal goals upwards. If at the beginning of 2024 Pop Mart predicted a turnover of 2,800 million dollars (around 2,400 million euros), in August Wang raised this target to 4,200 million dollars (3,600 million euros), pointing to the brand's global momentum as a key factor. Founded in Beijing in 2010, Pop Mart has established itself as one of the main Asian references in the toy and collectible figures sector, combining exclusive design, limited editions and collaborations with international brands, artists and franchises. Its business model is based on so-called “surprise boxes”, which encourage repeat purchases and have created a community of fans willing to pay high premiums for rare pieces. Among its main lines is Labubu, a monster with pointy ears and a mischievous smile inspired by Norse mythology, created by Hong Kong artist Lung Ka-sing in 2015 and integrated into the company's portfolio in 2019.

item.title: DSPA | Renewed Director Service Committee
item.description: Ip Kuong Lam's service commission as director of Environmental Protection Services has been renewed for a period of one year, according to an order published yesterday in the Official Gazette. As happens in these situations, the order indicates that the appointee has “appropriate experience and professional capacity to carry out his duties”. Ip Kuong Lam has a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in Environmental Engineering. He entered the public service in 2001, and served as senior technician at the Environment Council, head of the Environmental Pollution Control Department at DSPA and deputy director of DSPA, between 2014 and 2024, when he was promoted to his current position. IH | Iam Lei Leng's term renewed The mandate of the president of the Housing Institute (IH), Iam Lei Leng, was renewed for a period of one year, according to an order published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. Iam was first appointed to these roles in 2023, during Raimundo do Rosário's period as Secretary for Transport and Public Works. The renewal of the mandate was justified by the fact that Iam had “appropriate experience and professional capacity to carry out his duties”. Before being appointed president of IH, Iam Lei Leng headed the Department of Studies at the Housing Institute since March 2015. The current president joined IH, as a technician, in April 1999, remaining in the position for around a year. Between June 2002 and January 2006, he became a senior technician. After completing this mission, he became head of Legal Affairs at the Housing Institute, where he remained until 2015. Commerce | António Lei dismissed as managing director António Lei Chi Wai was dismissed from the position of managing director of the Board of Directors of the Macau World Trade Center, according to information released yesterday in the Official Bulletin. Lei will be replaced by Ao Weng Tong, currently a member of the Consumer Council and who will hold both roles. The decision by the Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, was published yesterday in the Official Bulletin, but came into force on November 19th. The order does not make it clear whether António Lei Chi Wai will continue to serve as president of the Executive Committee of the Macau World Trade Center. Currently, António Lei has an annual salary of 1.2 million patacas, for both roles, which if divided over 12 months represents a salary of 100 thousand patacas.

item.title: Finance | Reserve with biggest increase until September since the pandemic
item.description: In nine months, the value of reserve assets increased by 42.5 billion patacas, exceeding last year's figure. Macau's financial reserve is at its highest level since April 2021, with a value of 658.8 billion patacas The financial reserve had the best first nine months of the year since 2019, before the start of the covid-19 pandemic, it was announced yesterday. According to a balance sheet published in the Official Bulletin by the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM), the value of assets rose by 42.5 billion patacas in the first nine months. Official data show that this is the best start to the year since the first nine months of 2019, a period in which the reserve appreciated by 64.7 billion patacas. According to AMCM, the reserve has already appreciated more than in 2024, the year in which assets rose by 35.7 billion patacas, the highest annual value since the pandemic. Last year recorded the highest increase since 2019, when the value of Macau's financial reserve rose by 70.6 billion patacas. In September alone, the reserve gained 5.49 billion patacas, reaching 658.7 billion patacas, the highest value in more than four years. Macau's financial reserve is at the highest level since recorded in April 2021, at 658.8 billion patacas. Still, it remains below the historical record of 663.6 billion patacas, reached at the end of February 2021, despite the territory being in the midst of a pandemic at the time. The inside of the melon The value of the extraordinary reserve at the end of September this year was 456.5 billion patacas and the basic reserve, equivalent to 150 percent of Macau's public budget, was 167.3 billion patacas. Subcontracted investments represent the largest share of Macau's financial reserve, 281.3 billion patacas, which also includes deposits and current accounts worth 265.4 billion patacas and even credit securities worth 109.4 billion patacas. In 2024, investments yielded almost 31 billion patacas to the financial reserve, corresponding to a profitability rate of 5.3 percent, said AMCM, at the end of February. The territory's initial budget for 2025 predicted a 7 percent increase in total expenditure, to 109.4 billion patacas. But the Legislative Assembly (AL) approved in July a proposal presented by the Government for a new budget, which includes an extra increase of 2.86 billion patacas in expenses. On Tuesday, the AL also unanimously gave the green light to the budget for 2026, which foresees public expenditure of 113.5 billion patacas.

item.title: National security | Government will create risk alert system
item.description: Guardianship debates continue on the report on the Lines of Government Action for 2026. Yesterday the Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, guaranteed that in 2026 a risk alert system for national security will be created The Macau Government promised to create, in 2026, a risk warning system for national security and warned of “acts of interference and destruction” by “external forces”. The Secretary for Security set the goal for next year to implement “a system of monitoring and warning indicators of risks related to the defense of national security”. Chan Tsz King, who until December 2024 served as commissioner against Corruption, spoke during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action (LAG) for 2026, in the Legislative Assembly (AL). The former prosecutor promised to “remain highly vigilant in the face of the new and complex panorama” of international security and warned of “multiple factors of uncertainty that could compromise the security of the State”. Prevention matters Macau will “strictly prevent acts of interference and destruction [by] external forces”, guaranteed Chan, highlighting the importance of guaranteeing security in “major events”. Between the 9th and 21st of November, the regions of Macau, Hong Kong and Guangdong hosted the 15th edition of the National Games. On November 18, the Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, said that Macau received 2,480 people in delegations to the National Games. More than two million tourists passed through the city during the event. During yesterday's LAG debate, MP Lam Lon Wai defended the creation of “standardized security guidelines and procedures” for large events, including concerts. Chan Tsz King, who took office on October 16, promised to study Lam Lon Wai's suggestion, but stressed that authorities already have “specific [security] plans for different types of activity”. The secretary said that this year, the police “effectively prevented and investigated crimes against national security, deterring and combating anti-China and disruptive Macau individuals.” On July 31, local police authorities announced the arrest of former deputy and pro-democracy activist Au Kam San, a Portuguese citizen, in the first case under the region's national security law, which came into force in 2009 and whose scope was expanded in 2023. Last Thursday, the head of the European Union (EU) Delegation in Hong Kong and Macau wrote on social media that he had met with Macau's Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip. “I also expressed concern about political issues,” added Briton Harvey Rouse. But the EU representation declined to reveal whether the case of Au Kam San was mentioned at the meeting. Smuggling | Secretary highlights stability The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, stressed that the security situation in the territory is stable. “Between January and October 2025, the crime rate in Macau decreased compared to the same period in 2024”, he said, highlighting “the decreasing trend” in crimes such as “serious violence, theft, theft and computer fraud”, so “security in general remains stable and good”. However, Chan Tsz King highlighted the occurrence of several cases of smuggling, and in the first ten months of the year alone, 108 people “of school age” were intercepted, “seven times more than the same period” last year. The secretary also spoke of the occurrence, this year, of 126 cases of smuggling detected by the Customs Services. "We have established a communication mechanism with schools to reinforce compliance with the law. We will resort to a cooperation mechanism with the three parties [Hong Kong, Macau and Guangdong] to combat smuggling."

item.title: Video surveillance helped police solve more than 38 thousand cases
item.description: Video surveillance cameras have helped solve more than 38 thousand cases since they began to be installed on the city's streets. “From 2016 until now we have been able to solve 38 thousand cases through” the network of surveillance cameras, the general commander of the Unitary Police Services (SPU) of Macau, Leong Man Cheong, told deputies yesterday. During the first five phases of the Macau City Video Surveillance System, known as ‘Eyes in the Sky’, more than 1,920 cameras were installed throughout the region. In 2023, the SPU said that the system had helped investigate cases of homicide, drug trafficking, robbery, theft, arson, possession of a prohibited weapon, offenses against physical integrity and fraud. Leong Man Cheong revealed that the sixth phase of 'Eyes in the Sky' will include the installation of an additional 800 video surveillance cameras by the end of 2027, including 120 on a new artificial island, known as zone A. "We have already installed ten cameras in several public housing buildings, which have come into operation. In addition, surveillance cameras have been installed on the main roads," added the commander. Leong stressed that the installation of the remaining cameras “must follow the technical progress of construction” and urbanization of zone A. The official was speaking at the Legislative Assembly during the debate on the Lines of Government Action for 2026, presented by the Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King. The missing solution In the same debate, Chan pointed to new technologies, including artificial intelligence, as the solution to dealing with “the lack of personnel” in the territory's security forces. “Within two to three years, several workers will reach retirement age, so we will then see that the problem will be more serious”, warned the secretary. But Chan stressed that “all leaders” in Macau have to “face certain limitations” due to “the Government’s general policy” for hiring public servants. “We have to be pragmatic, realistic and we also have to take into account the use of new technologies to overcome this gap”, defended the former prosecutor. Despite the limitations, Chan assured that he will not give up on the fight against illegal work and revealed that security forces have detected, “so far this year”, 76 cases involving 173 people. An increase compared to the same period in 2024, in which the police registered 63 cases involving 117 people, with the majority of illegal workers coming from Mainland China, Hong Kong and Southeast Asia.

item.title: Public consultation on new money laundering law in 2026
item.description: The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, assured that the public consultation will be launched in the coming months to review the law to combat terrorism and money laundering. “We will improve the diplomas related to money laundering, and next year launch the respective legislation and carry out public consultation, so that the future proposed law has everyone's consent”, stressed the secretary. It should be noted that the measure is included in the LAG report, released last week. The document reads that the changes to the 2006 law, relating to the prevention and repression of the crime of money laundering, and to the administrative regulation, also from that year, which legislates measures of a preventive nature against the crimes of money laundering and terrorist financing, aim to “respond to the latest changes introduced to international standards for combating money laundering and trends in this crime”. Make accounts easier One of the deputies who spoke about the need to improve this legislation was Ip Sio Kai. "Many times, those holding positions in companies face problems in setting up companies taking into account the diplomas in force, and this has been an impediment and deterrent factor. When an account is opened it has to be verified several times. Singapore is a financial center and also has a gambling sector, why is it so easy there to open accounts and set up companies compared to Macau? When it comes to financial security, there is no clear limit on the demands, one cannot demand too much in terms of requirements, and people don’t know how to proceed”, he defended. Even so, the deputy, linked to the financial area, praised the activity of the Financial Information Office. "The results have been good and we have even received praise. But can the authorities define and present different requirements in relation to risks of different levels? I agree that a legislative review should be carried out to increase the requirements."

item.title: Commerce | Song Pek Kei wants more support
item.description: Deputy Song Pek Kei yesterday called on the Government to promote the extension of the Consumer Grand Prix to support the local market. The position was taken in an intervention before the agenda, in the Plenary of the Legislative Assembly. In his intervention, Song began by outlining a scenario of difficulties in local commerce: “Due to the multiple impacts resulting from the consumption drain, the internet economy and the change in consumption, Macau's community economy is no longer as prosperous as before”, he pointed out. “The business space for physical stores is increasingly narrow, the pressure on exploitation is increasing, the opportunities to make money are fewer, the companies that can survive are in a very difficult situation, and many companies even choose to close their businesses because they suffer considerable losses, so there are many unoccupied stores in Macau”, he described. In this difficult environment, Song called for more measures to support residents' consumption to promote Macau's domestic economy. “The Macao SAR Government should, if financial conditions allow, study the launch of new consumption subsidy plans […] in order to increase subsidy plans and specific benefits for electronic products, household appliances, meals, etc., with the aim of continuing to stimulate the community economy, stabilizing confidence in social development”, he appealed.

item.title: Game | Pereira Coutinho calls for greater investment in the face of regional competition
item.description: Despite economic diversification efforts, José Pereira Coutinho alerted authorities to the development of the gaming sector, so that the industry is not overtaken by regional competition. The warning from the deputy linked to the Macau Public Service Workers Association (ATFPM) was left in an intervention at the Legislative Assembly. "Due to the excessive dependence on a single industry, the Government of Macau has continued to work on economic diversification with the aim of creating and increasing other revenues from different economic activities to cover the constant annual increase in public expenditure. But this work has not been easy", said Coutinho. “The Macao SAR’s public revenues continue to come disproportionately from the gaming industry, representing around 86.2 percent of the total collected between January and July 2025”, he pointed out. Therefore, the legislator warns that it will not be difficult to find alternative sources of income, so it is necessary not to forget the care to be taken with the gaming industry. “The Government of Macau must make an effort to implement policies that increase the competitiveness of the gaming industry in the face of high competition from adjacent regions that operate under much more advantageous conditions, both in terms of taxation and the payment of commissions”, he stressed.

item.title: Germany's Strategic Awakening (II)
item.description: “The claim that a state’s security interest necessarily coincides with that of its citizens appears downright absurd.” Ole Nymoen If the draconian dictates of the Morgenthau Plan proposed by the United States in 1944 to demilitarize and deindustrialize Germany after World War II, transforming it into an agrarian country and incapable of starting new conflicts remained a dead letter, it was only because, in those same months, awareness of a fundamental conflict in Europe with the Soviet Union began to mature in the United States. As the weeks went by, the priority stopped being the neutralization of Germany and became preventing Moscow from absorbing it into its sphere of influence. In the interpretation of several American officials at the time, before reaching the Atlantic, the Red Army would have to seize the industrial capabilities of the Rhineland and the Ruhr region, the historic heart of German industry, with emphasis on the coal, steel, chemical, energy and logistics sectors. Hence the need to rebuild a West German state and direct its economic, human and technological potential against Soviet expansionism. Summarized in a 1949 CIA document, the United States' objective became “the permanent control of German power”. Eighty years later, the contours have changed, not the substance. Today, for Washington, the challenge of the century is called China, and the costs of defending the Old Continent must fall on the Europeans. France and the United Kingdom's financial room for maneuver is limited, also due to their expensive nuclear arsenals. And, from the point of view of the Poles, Balts and Scandinavians, Russia is an existential threat, to be contained and eroded by all means. Everything points in a single direction, which is German rearmament. According to this logic, it will be up to Germany to ensure the critical mass of economic resources and conventional forces that the remaining Western partners cannot or do not want to mobilize. Naturally, an essential assumption of this bet is that Berlin does not act on its own, building a sphere of influence or pursuing strictly national interests. Only then can it be understood that the Federal Republic, whose legal system theoretically prohibits even the sending of weapons to areas of armed conflict, is currently debating whether to place troops on the ground in Ukraine. In recent years, the Germans have broken several long-standing taboos, such as the debt brake, but this would be, for obvious reasons, the most clamorous. Thus, in August, at the end of the Washington summit, Merz stressed that Germany has a “fundamental interest” in cooperating to offer guarantees to Kiev, with the image of the chancellor in the role of a sinister Uncle Sam, accompanied by the caption that “Merz wants to send you to Ukraine? Not us!” To this day, this is not only an unpopular perspective according to a recent poll, as 51 percent of Germans are against it and only 36 percent are in favor, but it is also technically impractical. Despite the significant increase in military expenditure, the number of personnel in the German Armed Forces continues to decline and age. The objective of 203,000 units by 2031 seems out of reach, a goal that the strategic community of Berlin-Mitte, the most central and historic district of Berlin, considered the political, cultural and tourist heart of the German capital, considers totally insufficient to meet current German security needs. In the last three years, the approximately 180 thousand employees have decreased slightly. It is difficult to imagine that the military service reform recently approved by the federal government could represent the solution, as recruitment, for now, will continue to be voluntary. We are not, therefore, faced with a linear process. But it is worth remembering that, no matter how much legions of experts strive every day to present German rearmament as the panacea for all the ills of the West, it continues to be a high-risk bet. Above all because the European strategic context is radically different from the one that, in the post-war period, led Washington to allow itself to be convinced by London and Paris not to abandon Europe. At the time, it was French leaders, particularly figures like Robert Schuman and Jean Monnet, who firmly argued that any withdrawal of American troops would have “disastrous consequences” for the national security of the victors. And in the United States there was full awareness that the rapprochement between France and Germany was a fundamental condition for giving solidity to the Western bloc. As Secretary of State Dean Acheson, who played a central role in formulating American foreign policy during the early years of the Cold War, stated in 1949, “Only France can take the decisive lead in the integration of Germany in Western Europe… if it is to avoid Russian or German or perhaps Russian-German domination in Europe.” Having all due consideration for the pro-European rhetoric, without the security guarantees of the United States there would not have been any Franco-German axis, the true engine of European integration. The proof is there for all to see and is it a coincidence that the partial American disengagement with the continent coincides today with a crisis in relations between Germany and France? Washington seems increasingly distant. Old wounds resurface, never fully healed. In particular, the origin of tensions between the two banks of the Rhine lies in an opposing perception of German rearmament. Paris fears that the Federal Republic could transform into an assertive power unrelated to any control. Berlin, for its part, suspects that the French intend to use German funds to further their expensive ambitions. This is a structural fracture, impossible to completely bridge, regardless of the good will of Merz and Macron. (Continues)

item.title: Attachment Theory and the new “Astrology”
item.description: Attachment theory, for decades confined to academic articles and psychology offices, entered popular culture. From one moment to the next, we find people describing themselves as “anxious”, “avoidant” or “disorganized” with the same ease with which they declare their astrological sign. Clinical language entered common sense, attachment styles came to life in memes and reels on TikTok, and intimacy began to be talked about like someone reading an astral chart. I'm like this, you're like this. There is something irresistible about this trend. In times of uncertainty, the promise of a clear explanation for our emotional patterns has a quasi-therapeutic effect. Typification offers a vocabulary: we can finally express, in a few words, why we feel too attached to one relationship or too disconnected from another. And for many, there is genuine relief in recognizing that certain behaviors—the urgency of a response, the impulse to disappear—are not random but learned strategies for surviving emotionally. However, as this theory became mainstream, it also gained a more complicated side. The speed of social media has simplified complex concepts until they almost lost nuance. What was supposed to be a lens became a label; what could help to understand, began to imprison. And this is where the frustration arises: the feeling that attachment theory has been transformed into a kind of emotional determinism. It's common to hear statements like “I'm avoidant, that's how I am”, or “he'll never be able to give me what I need, because he's anxious”. Each of them reveals, at the same time, a desire for understanding and a certain resignation. Typification, when used as a sentence, gives comfort but takes away agency: it facilitates explanations, but impoverishes the complexity of human experience. Even more serious, it can serve to excuse behavior or to pathologize the other. However, attachment theory, when applied sensitively—especially in couples therapy—becomes a revealing tool. Instead of reducing the person to their standard, it allows us to look at what that standard tries to protect. It shows that our reactions in adult life are echoes of our first experiences of care; They are not destinations, but paths that we can deviate from, if we understand them. Let's think about the case, so common in therapy, of the couple in which one partner seeks contact and the other withdraws. On the surface, it seems incompatible. But, when the two begin to explore their own history, it is discovered that what today manifests itself as “anxiety” or “avoidance” was born from very different contexts. There are those who grew up in an environment where care was inconsistent: sometimes present, sometimes absent. These people learn to be vigilant, to interpret any silence as rejection. In adult relationships, they get closer when they are afraid of losing. Others grew up in families where autonomy was the only safe way to exist. They learned not to depend, not to ask not to take risks. In a relationship, they move away when intimacy intensifies — not because they don't feel it, but because feeling too much has always been dangerous. When these two worlds meet, they form a painful cycle: the more one party seeks connection, the more the other withdraws; and the more the latter retracts, the more the former intensifies the search. And this is precisely where typing becomes useful: illuminating patterns. In therapy, when a partner can say “I'm not staying away because I don't care, but because I'm overwhelmed,” something changes. And when the other person is able to recognize “I don't want to pressure you; I just need to feel that you're still here”, a new space of vulnerability opens up. The attachment theory thus makes it possible to transform misunderstandings into bridges. It gives language to silences, context to reactions, humanity to disagreements. It shows that no one is anxious “just because”, nor essentially avoidant: we are all the result of complex stories, shaped by what life has taught us about love. The problem, therefore, is not in the theory, but in the way pop culture simplifies it. When we reduce attachment styles to caricatures we miss the opportunity to see the emotional richness behind these strategies. And, perhaps most importantly, we forget that attachment is malleable. In the end, perhaps we should look at this trend in the same spirit with which we read a good horoscope: a mix of curiosity, lightness and critical sense. Attachment theory can be a valuable map, as long as we don't confuse the map with the territory. Words and definitions are only worth it if they give us freedom.

item.title: Pre-prepared food (II)
item.description: Last week, we looked at the recent online controversy surrounding pre-prepared food. Mainland China had issued a “Notice on Strengthening Food Safety Supervision of Pre-Prepared Food and Promoting High-Quality Development of Industry.” The Notice explains what “pre-prepared food” is and states that food that is prepared in the central kitchens of restaurant chains in accordance with food safety laws and regulations, and then distributed through their branches, is therefore not considered pre-prepared food. Although there are different definitions of pre-prepared food, for most consumers, as long as the food is not cooked in the restaurant, and if it contains ingredients that have signs of having been industrially processed, whether they are ready meals or semi-finished products, they are considered “pre-prepared food”. In other words, “if they are not freshly cooked, they are pre-prepared” is the widespread perception. Pre-prepared meals are ubiquitous in modern restaurant chains. The standardized taste ensures that consumers have the same experience regardless of which group restaurant they visit. This procedure encourages consumer loyalty to the brand. Restaurants do not gain or lose customers because of the quality of the chef. Pre-prepared food reduces the number of staff required, reducing payroll costs and increasing restaurant efficiency. We have a society where people order take-away every day; restaurants need to time food preparation and couriers need to time delivery times. If food preparation is not fast enough, restaurants cannot survive the competition. To ensure efficient food preparation, restaurants inevitably need to use pre-prepared food. Driven by restaurant needs, the demand for pre-prepared food has increased exponentially. Studies indicate that this market in mainland China will reach 1,072 billion dollars in 2026, with the potential to develop into the next market valued at billions of dollars. Therefore, it is essential to establish national food safety standards in the country. Restaurants' focus on serving food quickly leads consumers to view pre-prepared food as “fast food”. Therefore, they may not be willing to pay high prices for this type of food. Furthermore, customers expect to feel the “wok hei” (the smoky aroma imparted by a hot wok during meal preparation) and enjoy “freshly made” cuisine when they come to the restaurant. If food is prepared in the chain's central kitchen with pre-packaged ingredients, customers will experience a “psychological gap” that causes a series of issues. For example, is the food I am eating past its expiration date? Does it contain preservatives? Are these preservatives harmful to health? Does it affect the taste of food? If flavor and freshness are affected, should the price be lowered? These questions easily give rise to doubts. If consumers are forced to pay high prices for pre-prepared food, they may feel cheated and come into conflict with the restaurant. This controversy made society realize that if consumers “eat happily and calmly” they will return, which will be advantageous for customers and the restaurant. Perhaps it could be considered indicating on the menu whether the dish is “freshly made”, whether it comes from the “central kitchen of the restaurant chain” or whether it is “pre-prepared”, thus giving the consumer the possibility of choice. One such restaurant chain in mainland China, “Lao Xiang Ji,” uses this method by indicating whether meals are “made in the restaurant,” “semi-prepared,” or “reheated pre-prepared food.” This method satisfies customers, freeing them from misunderstandings and concerns about pre-prepared food and food safety. Lao Xiang Ji's approach imposed itself on industrialization, thus managing to retain customers. Furthermore, restaurants must understand that a transparent and honest environment better informs consumers, which increases their trust in restaurants. Consumer trust is the foundation of all brands. Consumers are both participants and drivers of the food industry. This controversy will help the food industry develop in a more standardized and healthy direction. To support this development, mainland China needs to implement national standards for the safety of pre-prepared meals as soon as possible and establish a strict quality control and tracing mechanism, which will be more beneficial to society. According to Macau Law No. 5/2013, the “Food Safety Law”, pre-prepared meals must be packaged securely and their ingredients must be labeled, but restaurants are not required to indicate whether or not their dishes use pre-prepared ingredients. This controversy demonstrates that consumers are concerned about restaurants serving pre-prepared meals. Given the current tendency for Macau residents to go shopping to mainland China, in order to survive, the restaurant industry needs to improve to attract more tourists. Perhaps Macau restaurants could consider explaining to customers that if they use locally pre-prepared food, they are serving typical dishes, “Made in Macau.” If they use pre-prepared foods sourced from mainland China and processed in their kitchens, they may identify them as “Made in mainland China + Processed in Macau” as a marketing slogan. In this way, operational costs can be reduced and the perception of the value of what is “Made in Macau” can be increased. After all, our tourism industry depends on tourists, and selling typically local products to tourists is the key to the city's business survival. Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor at the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University Email: cbchan@mpu.edu.mo

item.title: Presidents for all tastes
item.description: The electoral campaign for candidates for President of the Republic is on the road. The suitors for the Belém palace are more than many and for all tastes. On January 18th of next year, the Portuguese people are, once again, called to go to the polls to vote for whoever intends to be the new President of Portugal. There are candidates from the extreme right to the extreme left. The vote is secret, but most people already have an idea who they will vote for. One thing is certain: the Portuguese want to continue living in democracy and do not accept xenophobic, racist and neo-Nazi theories. Polls are worth what they are worth. They usually make mistakes in the final result. However, certain television channels have done everything to influence the vote in a certain direction. Today, I leave you with what we think of each of the candidates. André Ventura – A candidate anti-current political system, who has defended hatred for immigrants, who advocates a change in nationality laws and even in the Constitution of the Republic itself. It is clear that he is only running to try to maintain his electoral base for future legislative elections, despite the fact that his Chega Party has been losing followers. In the television debates he has participated in, he only knows how to shout and present the same arguments that he has announced since he founded the party. It is not even possible that he will be able to participate in a possible second round of the presidential elections. Marques Mendes – The former television commentator and PSD leader decided to run because his partner Luís Montenegro assured him that he would have the support of the PSD/CDS Democratic Alliance, which currently governs the country. Marques Mendes presents himself as a faction candidate. Without a doubt, supporters of the Montenegro government will vote for him. However, not all PSD activists support this candidacy. For these activists, Marques Mendes is Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa number two, with less knowledge of constitutional legislation. The polls created for his appreciation have already presented him as being ahead of voting intentions. We sincerely do not believe that the people will choose a President who would just go to Belém to defend all of Montenegro's proposals. Almirante Gouveia e Melo – A candidate who immediately received, upon announcing his candidacy, overwhelming popular support for having been a man of seriousness and organization when the Covid-19 virus pandemic hit. Some once again support a military man for the Presidency of Portugal. Others are radically against the election of a military officer. They say he has no political experience and cannot explain what political area he is in. How can a citizen who becomes an admiral not know politics? How is it that you have not followed the vicissitudes of politics in the 50 years of democracy? Impossible. Gouveia e Melo knows perfectly well what support he has and what ideas he has to be a different President. The problem is that their political opponents know that Gouveia e Melo knows too much, for example, who received “gloves” in the acquisition of the high-tech submarines Arpão and Tridente, and there was no investigation by the Public Ministry when the German participants in the deal were arrested. His opponents want to remove him at all costs, as Gouveia e Melo knows all the ins and outs of those who want to remove him. He is one of the strong candidates to win the elections, in the first or second round. António José Seguro – An experienced candidate in politics and academic life where he has maintained extensive contact with young people. He was general secretary of the Socialist Party and after the “war” with António Costa he hibernated. After 10 years, he returns bringing with him his seriousness, his political knowledge of the Portuguese reality and his serenity in analyzing national problems. The Socialist Party, or a part of it, was forced to announce that it supported this candidate. Seguro thanked him for the support, but emphasized his independence. Safe since he announced his candidacy for President, he has gradually risen in the voting intentions of the Portuguese, especially among a moderate “centrão” that includes social democrats and socialists. You may be surprised and go on to a second round. Cotrim Figueiredo – A candidate who was leader of the Liberal Initiative, a party that is more similar to Chega than to the PSD. Cotrim could be a surprise, especially when it comes to voting among young people and women. Personally, he is a cordial person, knowledgeable about political dossiers, with experience in the corridors of the European Parliament and who presents himself as a defender of modern and reformist liberalism. It may surprise in the percentage of votes, but we don't believe it will be enough to contest a second round. The mobilization around Cotrim is being active and influential. Its result will depend greatly on the criticisms it announces against Chega, otherwise, social democratic activists unhappy with Marques Mendes will not support him and may opt to vote for Seguro. António Filipe – This candidate is a Gentleman. Serious, deputy of the Assembly of the Republic for many years, knowledgeable about the Constitution from the first to the last paragraph, affable and popular. He does not deny his communist roots, but he often disagreed with the guidelines of the Central Committee of his party, the PCP. He is a candidate who has traveled the entire country and who sits in cafes listening to people's complaints. He has achieved a support base larger than that of his own party. We have already heard socialists saying that they will vote for his candidacy. António Filipe is cultured, an excellent commentator, a friend of the unprotected and could obtain a surprising result, despite the polls commissioned by the AD placing him as having no electoral significance. Maybe they are wrong. Catarina Martins – The candidate supported by the Bloco de Esquerda should have remained in the insignificance that has been registered in her party, which month after month has seen voters flee to Livre. Catarina has no chance of obtaining a good result, because the crisis raging in the Bloc does nothing to help her win over voters. She knows what she's talking about, she points out errors in Montenegro's governance, she defends the poverty-stricken pensioners, but there is no machine in her candidacy that could promote her to a credible candidate capable of achieving a good result. We will not comment on the candidate of Livre and other pretenders to the “throne” of Belém due to the fact that they have no chance of being elected. In our humble opinion, the elections will be disputed between Gouveia e Melo and Marques Mendes or António José Seguro. And in a second round, if Seguro is present, the entire left will be able to coexist with Álvaro Cunhal's thesis of covering his eyes and putting the cross on Seguro.

item.title: Edgar Martins wins Grand Prize Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize 2025
item.description: Photographer Edgar Martins won the Grand Prize of the Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize 2025, worth 25 thousand euros, for the work “Anton’s Hand is Made of Guilt”, inspired by the disappearance of a friend during wartime. The announcement was made this Tuesday, the day of the opening of the finalists' exhibition, at the Sociedade Nacional de Belas Artes, in Lisbon, during a press visit, led by Howard Bilton, founder and president of the Sovereign Art Foundation (SAF). This is the fourth edition of this annual award, which is awarded by the SAF Association, the Portuguese branch of the Sovereign Art Foundation, created in 2003 in Hong Kong to promote, support and recognize contemporary art and encourage artistic production, as well as financing programs for disadvantaged children in Portugal. The winning work, which is also present in the collection of the Museu de Arte Contemporânea Armando Martins (MACAM), is a chromogenic proof, mounted in aluminum and framed, which is part of the series “Anton’s hand is made of Guilt. No muscle of Bone. He has a Gung-ho Finger and a Grief-stricken Thumb” (2023). Edgar Martins' work explores themes such as war, incarceration, migration, urbanism and technology, with this project, in particular, focusing on the death and disappearance of a friend, photojournalist Anton Hammerl, during the Libyan war in 2011. Central questions The work is articulated around a central question: how to narrate a story without witnesses, evidence or traces, and in the absence of the photographic referent itself”, states the catalog information about the work, adding that “more than a tribute, this work portrays a complex story, distorted by absences, which talks about the difficulties of documenting, witnessing and imagining war”. "While I don't tend to categorize my work as photography in the traditional sense of the term, it is, in virtually every way, photographic. And photography, historically, has not been particularly successful when it is forced to compete with other mediums. So I received this news with surprise and excitement in equal measure. It is, of course, a huge honor to receive such a prestigious award. And what's more, a privilege to know that this financial support will directly contribute to the Sovereign Art Foundation's solidarity program, making me feel part of of something much greater than this isolated artistic feat”, declared the winner, quoted in a statement. For the president of the jury, David Elliott, it has not been an easy task to find a winner, with the “variety, depth and subtlety of the finalist works”. "The cruelly savage ironies that confront us in every daily news report are part of the theme of Edgar Martins' winning work. Rooted in both the present and the recent past, it was triggered by the still unexplained disappearance and death of his friend, photojournalist Anton Hammerl, during the Libyan War in 2011. It remains a crime without witnesses or any other evidence, a void that Martins has addressed in other works, as well as in the winning work 'Anton's Hand is Made of Guilt. In Muscle or Bone. He has a Gung-ho Finger and a Grief-stricken Thumb'”, said the president of the jury, quoted by the organization. In female This year, for the first time, the Women's Prize was created, created in partnership with the Sassy Women Society, worth two thousand euros, which distinguishes the finalist with the highest score, with the choice going to the artist Alice Marcelino, for the work “Black Skin White Algorithm”. As 30 obras finalistas vão estar expostas até ao dia 13 de Dezembro, data em que será atribuído o prémio do Voto Público, que pode ser feito presencialmente ou ‘online’, também no valor de dois mil euros. The 30 finalist works that will be on display were chosen by an international jury made up of seven experts – Adelaide Ginga, Armando Cabral, David Eliott, Francisco Trêpa (who won the grand prize in 2024), João Paulo Queiroz, Maura Marvão and Tim Marlow OBE – from around 200 artists proposed by a panel of independent arts professionals, including Portuguese critics, curators and academics. All finalist works are available for purchase and profits will be divided equally between the artists and SAF's expressive arts programs for disadvantaged children in Portugal. The Sovereign Portuguese Art Prize is an annual award that celebrates the work of contemporary artists living in Portugal and its diaspora, offering international recognition and financially supporting artists, whilst also raising funds for disadvantaged children in Portugal through the sale of finalist works.

item.title: Literature | José Cordeiro, former teacher in Macau, launches book of chronicles
item.description: It is with the approval of the Writing Workshop that José Cordeiro, who was a physical education teacher in Macau for several years, makes his literary debut. After many chronicles written on the social network Facebook, the encouragement of friends and readers led him to edit “Ao Invés, Pois Claro”, where there is not even a lack of text about what it means to be Macanese “Ao Invés, Pois Claro” is the title of the first book by José Cordeiro, former resident of Macau and former physical education teacher in the territory. With the approval of Oficina da Escrita, the book has just been published in Portugal and is the result of a series of publications, on different topics, published on the social network Facebook. According to the description of the work, it is not only a “collection of chronicles”, but also “an invitation to freedom of thought, the exploration of doubt and knowledge”, the “celebration of diversity of opinions” that is carried out with a “relaxed approach”. "I don't have any specific guidelines for writing a chronicle, it depends on the mood of the moment. It's not something doctrinal, it doesn't intend to influence anything. It's a personal pleasure I have, playing with words", he told HM. Although José Cordeiro has always made physical activity his profession, the truth is that the connection to letters has always existed. "I've always liked playing with words. I only started writing more systematically recently. I selected some chronicles, like a literary kitchen, where you make soup and a lot of it ends up going to waste", he exemplified. The themes are diverse and “cover religion, politics, friendship, everything and nothing”. One of the chronicles refers to Macau and being Macanese, a community issue that José Cordeiro knows well. In “State of siege or state of mind”, Cordeiro talks about the existence of the community and says that today, 25 years later, Macanese live “both things”. “It could be a state of siege, because they are limited to a community, which is Portuguese in Chinese territory, and a state of mind, because many people don't live in Macau, but feel Macanese living abroad”, he stressed. “Ao Invés, Pois Claro” is a name that was born from the author’s desire to be “a little contrary”. "They say I'm stubborn, and so it seems to me [so]. I don't comment on the comments they make on my chronicles, and when I launch a chronicle it stops being mine at that moment, it becomes those who interpret it", he said. The power of social networks José Cordeiro believes that “a good way for a person to discipline their reasoning is to write” and writing “is a way of disciplining my intervention in the contacts I make with people”. It's "having a clear idea and, as a first principle, expressing it. It was in a wave of fun that I started doing things, writing. There were people who liked the texts and suggested that I publish them". "I say it's an album because, for me, it's something else. It's when you take a theme and carry it through to the end", highlighted José Cordeiro, who confesses that social networks "have allowed everything", even giving voice to new authors. "Sometimes I feel uncomfortable with what is done [on social media], but I am responsible for myself and what I do. I have no intention of indoctrinating or wanting to take anyone wherever. I am a simple citizen who likes to play in my literary kitchen, as I usually call it", he said. José Cordeiro is still preparing a launch session for the work, but it is already for sale on several online platforms.

item.title: Jazz | Thai drummer Hong in concert on Saturday at FRC
item.description: Thai jazz drummer Chanutr Techatana-nan, better known as Hong, will perform at the Fundação Rui Cunha gallery on Saturday night. The musician will be accompanied on stage by members of the Macau Jazz Promotion Association. Entry is free The rhythmic engine of one of the most renowned jazz quartets on the Asian scene, The Asian All-Stars Power Quartet, will perform live at Fundação Rui Cunha (FRC) next Saturday, starting at 9pm. Anyone who passes by the FRC gallery will be able to watch the performance of Thai drummer Chanutr Techatana-nan, better known as Hong, accompanied by members of the Macau Jazz Promotion Association performing jazz classics and some original songs. The musician is described by the organizers of the event, in charge of the FRC and the Macau Jazz Promotion Association, as “a prominent figure in the Asian jazz scene, celebrated for his innovative drumming style that combines a groovy swing with intricate polyrhythmic embellishments”. In addition to praise for his performances and stage presence, Hong is a dedicated music teacher, a vocation he applies as an instructor and coordinator of the jazz studies program at Silpakorn University, in Thailand. With a career marked by collaboration with renowned musicians and participation in prestigious festivals around the world, “Hong is one of the influential figures in the musical genre, both as a performer and as an educator”. With the help of friends Born in Bangkok in 1978, Hong performed a little everywhere where jazz rhythms sound in Thailand. In 2002, his virtuosity was recognized with the “best drummer” award at the Thailand Drum Competition, an event organized in cooperation with the Percussive Arts Society. One of his facets as a music educator received greater acclaim with the release of the DVD “Over the Barline”, which received an avalanche of positive reviews. However, Hong's association with Singaporean pianist Jeremy Monteiro, also known as the “King of Swing”, would end up taking the Thai to perform all over the world, both with The Asian All-Stars Power Quartet and in the Organamix trio. In the quartet, Monteiro and Hong are accompanied by Hong Kong jazz guitarist Eugene Pao, and Filipino saxophonist Tots Tolentino. On Friday, starting at 6:30 pm, the FRC gallery will once again present “Uma Noite de Piano”, in a session “open to young talent” with a performance by Anson Lai. The event is co-organized by FRC and Elite – Association for Creativity and Musical Culture and has free entry.

item.title: IIM | Visit to historic neighborhoods scheduled for December 6th
item.description: The International Institute of Macau (IIM) will carry out two guided community visits to the historic neighborhoods of Macau, on December 6th. The tours, entitled “Macaense Neighborhoods: Roots of a Multicultural City”, will last around an hour and a half, with the first session scheduled for 2:30 pm and the second starting at 3 pm. The tours will start at Largo do Lilau, passing through Rua Central, Largo de Santo Agostinho, Rua da Felicidade, and end at the Dimensões M space, on Rua do Barão, close to the Seminário de São José, “where there will be a gathering and a drink”, indicates the IIM. The IIM initiative has the support of the Macau Foundation, and will be organized in partnership with the Association of Macau Heritage Ambassadors, and in collaboration with the Association of Young Macanese and Language Exchange and Culture Promotion. The visits were designed in conjunction with the twentieth anniversary of the inscription of the Historic Center of Macau on the World Heritage List and interested parties can now register on the social networks of the IIM and the Association of Macau Heritage Ambassadors. The event is free and will have a participation limit of 50 people for two separate sessions (25 people in each session). The IIM states that the objective of the initiative is to provide the public, especially younger people, with knowledge about the experiences and stories of historic neighborhoods, as well as their cultural identity.

item.title: ‘Satellite casinos’ | Kam Pek closes doors in Macau
item.description: Macau gaming concessionaire SJM Resorts announced yesterday that the Kam Pek Paradise 'satellite casino', with almost 600 employees, will close on December 1st. SJM said that Kam Pek Parasise “will officially cease operations at 23:59 (Monday, December 1st), thus becoming the seventh ‘satellite casino’ in the region to close its doors. In a statement, SJM, founded by gaming tycoon Stanley Ho Hung Sun (1921-2020), highlighted that all local employees directly hired by the company have guaranteed employment. SJM explained that staff with resident status in Macau will be “transferred to other company casinos to perform gaming-related functions, according to operational needs”. Local employees who were not hired directly by SJM Resorts “are invited to apply for related vacancies” within the group, “with priority for hiring” and with conditions equal to those they had. Also yesterday, the Macau Gaming Inspection and Coordination Department (DICJ) assured that it will “strictly supervise, on site, the closure procedures” of Kam Pek Paradise. With regard to the 584 casino employees, the DICJ assured, in a press release, that it will maintain communication with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs, to ensure compliance with the guarantees given by the SJM, namely “the relocation of all aforementioned workers”. SJM highlighted that “all tables and gaming machines currently operating on site will be transferred to other company casinos”.

item.title: TUI | Reduced sentence for man who tried to kill ex-wife
item.description: The Court of Final Instance (TUI) decided to reduce the prison sentence from 11 years and six months to eight years for a man convicted of attempted murder of his ex-wife, as “aggravating circumstances” had not been proven. The man was thus convicted of the attempted crime of simple homicide, in its attempted form, and decreed in the first instance by the Base Judicial Court (TJB), and not the crime of qualified homicide, also in its attempted form. The TUI understood that the man “only decided to attack B [his ex-wife] after having questioned her and realized that she would not pay the compensation” demanded by him. “Although it appears that the idea of ​​killing B [the woman] came to him since 2017, it was just a thought he had in his mind, and in the period from 2017 to April 2023, no action was taken to implement the idea of ​​killing”, it reads. The judges also considered, according to the ruling released yesterday, that “it is not clear that A [the accused man] acted coldly when attacking B [the woman]”, which is why the appeal presented by the man was upheld, considering the “excessive severity of the sentence determined” in the second instance. The case dates back to 2017, and the woman was already a victim of domestic violence during the relationship. The man “held a grudge” against the woman “for having reported his acts of domestic violence and other family disputes, giving him the idea of ​​killing her”. After the divorce, the man understood that his ex-wife had only obtained the Resident Identity Card (BIR) thanks to the marriage, so “he should pay her an amount as compensation”. The time of the crime The crime then began to enter into the plans of this man, who since April 2023 “kept a metal hammer in the box of his motorcycle”. On June 26 of that year, he stopped his motorcycle near his ex-wife's residence and “wandered around waiting for her”, then approached her and “demanded payment of the aforementioned compensation”. The woman ignored the man and walked away, and that was when the man “removed the metal hammer from the box of his motorcycle, ran after [her] and hit her in the head with the hammer”, and she “consequently fell to the ground”. The ruling describes that, “despite her fall, [the man] continued to hit the victim in the head with the hammer a total of five times, only stopping when he noticed that [the woman] was lying on the floor with decreased consciousness”. In the first instance, on July 31, 2024, the TJB convicted the man of committing a crime of attempted homicide and a crime of detention and use of a prohibited weapon, which, in legal terms, resulted in a sentence of eight years. Both the man and the Public Prosecutor's Office appealed to the second instance, which increased the sentence to 11 years and six months for the crime of attempted qualified homicide, crime of detention and use of a prohibited weapon. On February 14 of this year, the TUI accepted the convict's appeal and sent the case again to the Court of Second Instance (TSI), which repeated the trial and maintained the sentence of 11 years and six months in prison, but the man did not accept the decision and requested a new appeal, claiming that the TSI “did not fulfill its obligation to carry out a new trial, incurring an error in interpreting and applying the law”, determining “an excessively severe penalty”. The attacker has now managed to see his sentence reduced.

item.title: Tourism | Government signs agreement with Chinese mapping application
item.description: The Tourism Services Bureau (DST) and Gaode, a Chinese digital maps, navigation and location company, signed a strategic cooperation agreement that culminated yesterday in the launch of the “Smart Travel to Macau with One Click” platform. The function that can be used on the Mapa Gaode mobile phone application provides DST information, such as “festive events, real situations of points of tourist interest, traffic navigation and entertainment itineraries”, including information on food, accommodation, travel, entertainment. The application also has a “sharing function, encouraging users to exchange practical tips and travel strategies”. Furthermore, this year, Gaode classified Macau as the first priority city of “Super destinations abroad”. The platform dedicated to Macau has a list of street establishments, “reflecting the degree of popularity of traders from different sectors”, while also suggesting points of interest in community neighborhoods.

item.title: Cambodia | Money laundering suspicions in Macau
item.description: Companies linked to the Prince Holding group and Chen Zhi, accused of cybercrime, human trafficking and money laundering, conducted business in Macau and Hong Kong. One of the companies was Companhia de Vinho Pou Long, which operated in the Macao SAR and even organized a gala dinner for the elderly in 2020 Octopus tentacles from a dismantled scam center in Cambodia may have reached Macau and Hong Kong. An investigation by the HK01 portal revealed that companies related to billionaire Chen Zhi's criminal empire operated in the special administrative regions. The 37-year-old Chinese businessman is seen as the “brain behind a criminal empire” and is at the center of the largest cryptocurrency seizure in history, with around $14 billion in bitcoins confiscated by the United States Treasury Department. The schemes allegedly operated in industrial complexes in Cambodia, where foreign workers were forced to commit online fraud under armed surveillance. According to the Hong Kong publication, in the Prince Holding business universe, chaired by the Fujian businessman, there are companies that had business in Macau selling alcoholic beverages through a network of companies that had as a common denominator a businessman also active in Hong Kong: Qiu Yong. The businessman, who appears on the list of 146 companies and people sanctioned by the United States due to the alleged commission of the crimes mentioned above, holds passports from Cambodia and Saint Lucia, a small island in the Caribbean, and was the main shareholder of eight companies based in Hong Kong, two of which have already been dissolved. One of the companies based and operating in the neighboring region was the Wine Mini Store Digital Economy Industry Company, led together with Ng Sang Lei, a Macau resident and Macao SAR passport holder. A web in the delta The Wine Mini Store had a commercial address in Tsim Sha Tsui in the same place where several companies were headquartered that fugitive billionaire Chen Zhi controlled indirectly through offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands and companies in Hong Kong. Among the companies created and dissolved is the Pou Long Wine Company, based in Tsim Sha Tsui, which was fully owned by Ng Sang Lei before the commercial registration was annulled in October this year. According to reports in Macau in the past, the Pou Long Wine Company launched a series of activities, including a gala dinner for the elderly, in January 2020, which was attended by Qiu Yong. In February 2020, during the outbreak of Covid-19 in Wuhan, the Pou Long Wine Company donated 1.5 million patacas and 60,000 masks to the provincial authorities. In relation to the Macau resident, HM found references to Ng Sang Lei in the Official Gazette, when she was authorized by the Macau Monetary Authority to practice as an insurance intermediary in the Macao SAR in June 2019. Less than 10 months later, the resident was the target of an infringement procedure.

item.title: Exhibitions | More events but less money
item.description: Between January and September, 1,331 conventions and exhibitions were held in Macau, an increase of 25.7 percent year on year, or 272 events. The numbers were released yesterday by the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC). However, despite there being more events, the sector's profits were lower than in 2024. Revenue generated by convention and exhibition events was 3.72 billion patacas, which represented a reduction of 9.4 percent compared to the same period last year, when revenues reached 4.10 billion patacas. DSEC explained the reduction in annual revenue “mainly due to the drop in the number of visitors in general from abroad who came to the exhibitions”. The drop was most pronounced between January and June, with the third quarter being the exception. Compared to the third quarter, 385 convention and exhibition events were held, a year-on-year increase of 10.3 percent, and the number of participants and visitors was 567,000, up 8.2 percent year-on-year. Revenues were 2.02 billion patacas, an annual increase of 9.8 percent, given that in the third quarter of 2024 revenues did not exceed 1.84 billion patacas.

item.title: Retail | Turnover down 5.4 percent
item.description: Between January and September, retail trade turnover showed an annual reduction of 5.4 percent to 50.56 billion patacas. The data was released yesterday by the Directorate of Statistics and Census Services (DSEC). Among the reductions, the turnover of motor vehicle fuels and leather goods fell by 11.6 percent and 11.1 percent, respectively. On the opposite side, pharmacy turnover rose 7.8 percent. At the same time, the average sales volume index of retail establishments registered a year-on-year drop of 7.5 percent. The average sales volume index for watches and jewelry fell 19.6 percent, while that for pharmacies grew 8.2 percent. In relation to the fourth quarter of the year, DSEC indicates that 46.8 percent of retailers anticipate the stabilization of sales volume in annual terms, while 43.5 percent foresee a decrease, that is, they expect the situation to get even worse. However, 9.7 percent of businesspeople were optimistic and expected improvements. Despite the drop and the lack of optimism, when the analysis is made only taking into account the third quarter of this year, retail trade turnover grew 2.2 percent year-on-year, to 16.96 billion patacas.

item.title: Tourism | Room prices in luxury hotels fell 1.8%
item.description: On average, the price of rooms in five-star hotels in October registered an annual drop of 1.8 percent to around 1,572 patacas, in the month of Golden Week. In the first 10 months of this year, the decrease reached almost 5 percent The average price of a room in a five-star hotel last October was around 1,572 patacas, a figure that represented an annual drop of 1.8 percent. In the same month, which included the Golden Week holidays, the average occupancy rate remained at 94.2 percent, similar to that seen in 2024. The data was provided by the GGR Asia portal, based on the Macau Hotel Association's monthly survey, which collects information from 48 hotel units, 27 of which are five-star. According to the association's accounts, average room prices in five-star hotels have recorded consecutive annual drops in the last 16 months. Remember that the five-star segment dominates the city's hotel market. According to the latest official data, for the month of September, the total number of rooms in five-star hotels represented almost 60 percent of the approximately 44 thousand rooms available in Macau. The proportion is more significant considering that Government statistics include establishments below three stars. Glass almost full If in October the average price of a night in a five-star hotel room was 1,572 patacas, in the first 10 months of 2025 the average price is almost 60 patacas lower than the monthly figure, totaling 1,513 patacas, which represents an annual decrease of 4.8 percent. However, between January and the end of October, the occupancy rate of five-star hotels rose 2.3 percent year on year, to an average of 94.4 percent. Taking into account all hotels in Macau, regardless of the number of stars, in the first 10 months of 2025, the average occupancy rate reached 93.6 percent, 2.1 percent more compared to the same period in the past. The average price of a night fell 3.2 percent to around 1,352 patacas. Macau received 3.47 million visitors in October, 10.8 percent more than in the same period in 2024 and the highest figure ever for the month under analysis since the Government began compiling monthly data in 1998, still during the Portuguese administration. Between the 1st and 8th of October alone, the holiday period, 1.14 million tourists entered Macau. Despite record arrivals in October, with the increase in day-trippers or tourists opting for accommodation outside Macau, the number of overnight stays grew by just 1.7 percent.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died.
